'''Enrique Alvear Urrutia''' (31 January 1916 – 29 April 1982) was a [[Chilean people|Chilean]] [[Roman Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]] [[prelate]] who served as the [[Roman Catholic Diocese of San Felipe, Chile|Bishop of San Felipe]] from 1965 until 1974 when he was made one of the two [[Auxiliary bishop|auxiliaries]] for the [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Santiago de Chile|Santiago de Chile archdiocese]].<ref name=CR>{{citeweb|date=15 January 2018|accessdate=17 January 2018|publisher=Crux|title=Pope shakes up Chile trip with surprise visit to 'bishop of the poor'|url=https://cruxnow.com/pope-in-chile-and-peru/2018/01/15/pope-shaks-chile-trip-surprise-visit-bishop-poor/}}</ref> He was a vocal critic during the [[dictatorship]] of [[Augusto Pinochet]] and braved potential detention and [[death threats]] to condemn [[human rights abuses]] and other atrocities the regime undertook.
The process for his potential beatification opened in 2012 and he is titled as a [[Servant of God]]. He has also been referred to as the "bishop of the poor" for his dedication to the poor and oppressed.<ref name=CR/>
==Life== Enrique Alvear Urrutia was born on 31 January 1916<ref>Some sources suggest he was born on 29 January.</ref> in [[Cauquenes]] in [[Chile]] as the eighth of eleven brothers to Clorindo Alvear Zurita and Teodorinda Urrutia Pérez; his brother was Eduardo.
He spent his education first in his hometown and then in the Luis Campino Humanities Institute before he pursued a law degree from 1934 in the [[Pontifical Catholic University of Chile|Pontifica Universidad Católica de Chile]]. In one spiritual retreat of [[Monsignor]] Carlos Casanueva Opazo he discovered his call to the [[priesthood]] and he began his ecclesial studies.
He received his [[ordination]] to the priesthood in the [[Santiago Metropolitan Cathedral|Santiago Cathedral]] on 20 September 1941 from [[José María Caro Rodríguez]] and then started pastoral work in archdiocese. He first worked as a professor in addition to being a [[spiritual director]] for [[seminarians]]. [[Pope John XXIII]] appointed him in 1963 as a bishop assigned as one of the [[Auxiliary bishop|auxiliaries]] for the [[Talca]] diocese while making him the Titular Bishop of Columnata. He received his [[episcopal consecration]] a month after the appointment from [[Raúl Silva Henríquez]]; the [[co-consecrators]] were Manuel Larraín Errazuriz and Eladio Vicuña Aránquiz. In 1965 he was appointed as the [[Roman Catholic Diocese of San Felipe, Chile|Bishop of San Felipe]]; he held that position until he resigned in 1974. But since he was under the retirement age [[Pope Paul VI]] named him as one of the two auxiliaries for the Santiago archdiocese as well as the [[Diocese of Sita|Titular Bishop of Sita]].<ref name=CR/> He served as a [[Council Father]] in the [[Second Vatican Council]] in the second to fourth sessions.
He opposed [[human rights abuses]] during the [[Augusto Pinochet|Pinochet]] [[dictatorship]] and defended the regime's victims all the while braving potential detention and [[death threats]]. In the evening on 11 September 1973 - against the advice of his aides - he went to prisons to inquire about people who were rounded up in a wave of arrests as part of Pinochet's coup against the sitting [[President of Chile|President]] [[Salvador Allende]]. <ref name=CR/> There was also one occasion where bombs were placed in his office in a failed attempt to intimidate him into silence. He later became involved with the [[Latin American Episcopal Conference|Episcopal Conference of Latin America and the Caribbean]].
He died on 29 April 1982 and his remains were interred in the Marian shrine Nuestra Señora de Lourdes in [[Quinta Normal]] until their transferral on 13 April 2008 to the San Luis Beltrán church. [[Pope Francis]] - during his trip to Chile in 2018 - made an unscheduled visit to the late bishop's tomb for some brief moments of reflection.<ref name=CR/>
==Beatification process== The beatification process was initiated in the Santiago archdiocese; initial steps towards opening the cause came on 16 December 2011 when the then-Archbishop (now [[Cardinal (Catholic Church)|cardinal]]) [[Ricardo Ezzati Andrello]] named the Enrique Alvear Urrutia Foundation as the official actor for promoting the cause. Ezzati later inaugurated the diocesan phase for the cause on 9 March 2012 and closed it later on 3 December 2014; during 2013 the [[Congregation for the Causes of Saints]] declared "[[nihil obstat]]" (no objections) to the cause.<ref name=CR/>
The current [[postulator]] for the cause is the [[Society of Jesus|Jesuit]] priest Pascual Cebollada Silvestre.
==Notes and references== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://newsaints.faithweb.com/year/1982.htm Hagiography Circle] * [http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/bishop/balvurr.html Catholic Hierarchy] * [http://www.donenriquealvear.cl Official website]

revision.text:
{{Infobox museum | name = Ferdinand E. Marcos Presidential Center | native_name = | native_name_lang = | logo = | logo_upright = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | image = Ferdinand E. Marcos Presidential Center sign.jpg | image_upright = | alt = | caption = | map_type = | map_relief = | map_size = | map_caption = | coordinates = {{coord|18.055017|120.562857|type:landmark_region:PH|display=inline,title}} | former_name = | established = <!-- {{Start date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | dissolved = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | location = Brgy.10 – N Lacub, [[Batac, Ilocos Norte]] | type = | accreditation = | key_holdings = | collections = | collection_size = | visitors = | founder = | director = | president = | ceo = | chairperson = | curator = | architect = | historian = | owner = | publictransit = | car_park = | parking = | network = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | embedded = }} The '''Ferdinand E. Marcos Presidential Center''' is a museum situated in [[Batac, Ilocos Norte|Batac]], [[Ilocos Norte]] dedicated to former Philippine President [[Ferdinand Marcos]] which also hosts the [[cenotaph]] of the former President. The museum shows memorabilia of the late president, from his stint in the armed forces down to his presidency. The large cenotaph which contains the glass-encased coffin in which the widely believed embalmed body of Marcos was on public display shortly after his remains were brought in Ilocos Norte from the United States in 1993<ref>Eugene (2008-02-06) [http://www.vistapinas.com/article/marcos-museum-and-mausoleum Marcos Museum and Mausoleum] ''Vista Pinas'', retrieved January 14, 2012</ref><ref>[http://www.worldtourist.us/ilocosnorte/laoag.html The Province of Ilocos Norte] ''World Tourist'', retrieved January 14, 2012</ref> until his body was re-interred at the [[Heroes' Cemetery]] in [[Taguig]] on November 18, 2016. A wax replica of Marcos remains to be displayed inside the glass coffin.
==History== [[File:Marcos Monument Batac Ilocos Norte.jpg|thumb|220px|right|A statue of Ferdinand Marcos erected in [[Batac, Ilocos Norte]]]] ===Ferdinand E. Marcos' death=== On September 28, 1989, Marcos died of lung, kidney and liver complications in [[Hawaii]], three years after he, his family and allies were exiled. In 1986, Marcos fled the country in the face of a [[nonviolent revolution]] "[[People Power Revolution|people power]]" which set the end of his regime.<ref>Admin (2009-11-01) [http://www.valcaulin.com/article/marcos-mausoleum-in-batac-ilocos-norte/843/# Marcos Mausoleum in Batac, Ilocos Norte] ''Valerie Caulin'', retrieved January 14, 2012</ref> The odyssey of his remains began when the government of President [[Corazon Aquino]] denied Marcos' return to the Philippines.<ref>Seth Mydans (1988-05-25) [https://www.nytimes.com/1988/05/25/world/in-philippines-one-last-symbol-lies-in-state.html In Philippines, One Last Symbol Lies in State] ''[[New York Times]]'', retrieved January 15, 2012</ref> Thus Marcos' remains was interred in a private air conditioned mausoleum at [[Byodo-In_Temple#Modern_Hawai.27i|Byodo-In]], a [[Japanese Buddhism|Japanese Buddhist]] temple, on the island of [[Oahu]].<ref>Admin (2001-05-25) [https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/22512 Ferdinand E. Marcos] ''Find A Grave'', retrieved January 14, 2012</ref>
===Return of Marcos' remains=== In September 1993, after having been kept in a refrigerated, glass-topped coffin inside an air-conditioned crypt for four years, Marcos' remains were finally taken to the Philippines.<ref name="Seattle">William Branigin (1993-09-07) [http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=19930907&slug=1719891 Imelda Marcos Plans Funeral Extravaganza For Ex-Dictator – Hoopla Abounds As Body Arrives In Home Province] ''Seattle Times'', retrieved January 14, 2012</ref> The newly elected president who succeeded Aquino, [[Fidel Ramos]], second cousin of the late president, allowed [[Imelda Marcos]], Marcos' widow, to bring her husband's body home but refused her demand for a hero’s burial.<ref>Seth Mydans (2011-03-09) [https://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/10/world/asia/10marcos.html?_r=1 A Hero’s Burial for Long-Dead President Marcos? It’s Being Considered] ''[[New York Times]]'', retrieved January 14, 2012</ref>
Eventually, after series of rituals and ceremonies, Marcos' remains were interred in a mausoleum in his hometown for public display, according to his family<ref name="Seattle" /><ref>Yodi Insigne (2011-08-23) [http://www.yodisphere.com/2011/08/batac-city-ilocos-norte-understanding.html Batac City, Ilocos Norte » Understanding the Final Argument of a Dictator's Town] ''Yodisphere'', retrieved January 14, 2012</ref><ref>William L. Adams (2011-12-20) [http://newsfeed.time.com/2011/12/20/photos-will-kim-jong-il-become-the-worlds-latest-embalmed-leader/?slide=ferdinand-marcos#ferdinand-marcos Ferdinand Marcos] ''Time Newsfeed'', retrieved January 15, 2012</ref> President [[Benigno Aquino III]], son of the late Corazon and [[Benigno Aquino Jr.]], tasked [[Jejomar Binay]] to determine if Marcos should be buried in the Heroes' Cemetery.<ref>Jerry E. Esplanada (2011-06-03). [http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/11725/binay-recommendation-military-honors-for-marcos-burial-in-ilocos Binay recommendation: Military honors for Marcos burial in Ilocos] ''Philippine Daily Inquirer'', retrieved January 16, 2012</ref> Binay made his recommendation, though Aquino has not yet made a decision.<ref>Vincent Cabreza (2011-09-11). [http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/56721/malacanang-mum-on-binay-recommendations-for-marcos-burial Malacanang mum on Binay recommendations for Marcos burial] ''Philippine Daily Inquirer'', retrieved January 16, 2012</ref> Just recently, the new president, Rodrigo Duterte approved Marcos burial in the cemetery and was buried in the place on November 18, 2016.
===The remains of Ferdinand Marcos=== Frank Malabed, Marcos' mortician, states that he has helped preserve the body during its interment at the former mausoleum in Barac. It took him three weeks to restore Marcos' body so that [[Filipino people|Filipinos]] would recognize it. Local morticians maintain and check it regularly. [[Formaldehyde]] was used to preserve the body before it was flown to the Philippines.<ref>Archives (1992-04-03) [http://www.deseretnews.com/article/218855/MARCOS-UNDERTAKER-TO-READY-HIS-BODY-FOR-RETURN-HOME.html Marcos' Undertaker to Ready His Body for Return Home] ''Deseret News'' retrieved January 15, 2012</ref>
It was reported on August 2016, that Historian Antonio Montalvan II said that a close Marcos family friend of his revealed that the body displayed on the glass coffin was a wax figure and not the preserved remains of Ferdinand Marcos. Montalvan added that the real body of Marcos is buried underneath the glass coffin.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Pedroza|first1=Stephen|title=Are we really burying Marcos' 'body'?|url=http://www.rappler.com/move-ph/144664-marcos-necropolitics-bury|accessdate=21 November 2016|work=Rappler|date=31 August 2016}}</ref>
A wax replica of Marcos' remains was reportedly left inside the glass coffin on the day Marcos' real body was interred at the [[Heroes' Cemetery]]. There are reportedly two or three replicas of Marcos' body.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Cepeda|first1=Mara|title=‘Replica’ left in mausoleum on day of Marcos burial|url=http://www.rappler.com/newsbreak/inside-track/152973-replica-body-mausoleum-marcos-burial|accessdate=21 November 2016|publisher=Rappler|date=20 November 2016}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Burial of Ferdinand Marcos]] * [[Bantayog ng mga Bayani Center]] * [[Proclamation No. 1081]] * [[History of the Philippines (1965–86)]] * [[Kumsusan Palace of the Sun]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox President | name = Jafar Sharif-Emami | image = Jafar Sharif-Emami portrait.jpg | birth_date = 9 September 1910 | birth_place = [[Tehran]], [[Iran]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1998|6|16|1910|9|8|df=y}} | death_place = [[New York City]], [[United States]] | order3 = [[Senate of Iran|President of the Senate]] | term_start3 = 11 September 1964 | term_end3 = 24 March 1978 | monarch3 = [[Mohammad Reza Pahlavi]] | predecessor3 = [[Mohsen Sadr]] | successor3 = Mohammad Sajadi | order = [[List of Prime Ministers of Iran|38th]] | office = Prime Minister of Iran | term_start2 = 31 August 1960 | term_end2 = 5 May 1961 | monarch2 = [[Mohammad Reza Pahlavi]] | predecessor2 = [[Manouchehr Eghbal]] | successor2 = [[Ali Amini]] | term_start = 27 August 1978 | term_end = 6 November 1978 | monarch = [[Mohammad Reza Pahlavi]] | predecessor = [[Jamshid Amouzegar]] | successor = [[Gholam Reza Azhari]] |office4 = [[Foreign Minister of Iran|Minister of Foreign Affairs]] |term_start4 = 30 July 1960 |term_end4 = 1 December 1960 |primeminister4 = [[Manouchehr Eghbal]] |predecessor4 = [[Abbas Aram]] |successor4 = [[Hossein Ghods-Nakhai|Ghods-Nakhai]] | party = [[Rastakhiz Party]] | alma_mater = [[Tehran University]] | spouse = Eshrat Sharif Emami (died November 1997) | children = 3 | website = }} '''Jafar Sharif-Imami''' (9 September 1910 – 16 June 1998) was an [[Iranian peoples|Iranian]] politician who was [[Prime Minister of Iran|prime minister]] from 1960 to 1961 and again in 1978. He was a cabinet minister, president of the [[Iranian Senate]], president of the [[Bonyad#Monarchy|Pahlavi Foundation]] and the president of the Iran chamber of industries and mines during the reign of Shah [[Mohammad Reza Pahlavi]].<ref name="memoirs"/>
==Early life and education== [[Image:Sharif Emami, Shah.jpg|thumb|left|[[Mohammad-Reza Shah]] welcomes Sharif Emami and his government in [[Niavaran Palace]]]] [[File:Dr. Jafar Sharif-Emami (1976).jpg|thumb|left|Sharif-Emami as [[Senate of Iran|President of Senate]]]]
Sharif-Emami was born in [[Tehran]] on 8 September 1910 to a clerical family and his father was a mullah.<ref name=milani/> After high school, Sharif-Emami was sent (along with thirty other young men) to [[Germany]] where he studied for eighteen months, returning to Iran in 1930 to work with state railroad organization until the [[Anglo-Soviet invasion of Iran|Anglo-Soviet Invasion]].<ref name=milani/> Years later he was sent to [[Sweden]] for technical training, returning in 1939 when he received a degree in engineering.<ref name="memoirs"/>
==Career and activities== Sharif-Emami began his career the Iranian state railways in 1931.<ref name=saxonyt/> Arrested in summer of 1943 for alleged ties to Germany he was kept in detention along with many other members of Iran's elite. After his release he was appointed director general of the Irrigation Agency.<ref name="memoirs"/> In 1950, he was appointed undersecretary of roads and communications.<ref name=saxonyt/> In June 1950, prime minister and General Haj Ali Razmara appointed him acting minister and then minister of roads, his first cabinet post.<ref name="memoirs"/>
He served as the minister of industries and mines in [[Manuchehr Eqbal]]'s cabinet.<ref name="Avsati">'Alí Rizā Awsatí (عليرضا اوسطى), ''Iran in the Past Three Centuries'' (''Irān dar Se Qarn-e Goz̲ashteh'' - ايران در سه قرن گذشته), Volumes 1 and 2 (Paktāb Publishing - انتشارات پاکتاب, Tehran, Iran, 2003). {{ISBN|964-93406-6-1}} (Vol. 1), {{ISBN|964-93406-5-3}} (Vol. 2).</ref> He was prime minister from 1960 to 1961, and again in 1978, a few months before the overthrow of the Shah.<ref name=saxonyt/> He was appointed prime minister by Shah on 27 August 1978 because of his ties to clergy.<ref name=Moaddel1994>{{cite book|author=Mansoor Moaddel|title=Class, Politics, and Ideology in the Iranian Revolution|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cgt2XSOuVgoC&pg=PA160|accessdate=25 July 2013|date=January 1994|publisher=Columbia University Press|isbn=978-0-231-51607-5|pages=160}}</ref> Sharif-Emami succeeded [[Jamshid Amouzegar]] in the post.<ref name=Moaddel1994/><ref>{{cite journal|last=Nikazmerad|first=Nicholas M.|title=A Chronological Survey of the Iranian Revolution|journal=Iranian Studies|date=1980|volume=13|issue=1/4|pages=327–368|jstor=4310346|doi=10.1080/00210868008701575}}</ref>
During his short tenure, he undid many of the Shah's plans including the closing of casinos, abandoning the Imperial calendar, abolishing the [[Rastakhiz Party|Rastakhiz]] Party and allowing all political parties to be active and personally responsible for preventing SAVAK to get involved and preventing the KGB backed clergyman from creating and continuing the 1979 revolution.<ref name="Avsati"/> All of his efforts to reform the political system in Iran, was overshadowed by the [[Black Friday (1978)|Black Friday]] massacre in Jaleh Square (8 September 1978), mass protests, martial law and nationwide strikes, which brought the country's economy to its knees. He resigned from office amid riots on 5 November 1978.<ref name=bbconthisd>{{cite news|title=On this day. 5 November 1978: Iran's PM steps down amid riots|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/november/5/newsid_2538000/2538427.stm|accessdate=25 July 2013|newspaper=BBC}}</ref> [[Gholam Reza Azhari]] replaced him in the post.<ref name=saxonyt/> He was also long-time president of [[Iranian Senate|the Iranian senate]]<ref name=cia72>{{cite web|title=Centers of Power in Iran|url=http://2001-2009.state.gov/documents/organization/70712.pdf|work=CIA|accessdate=5 August 2013|date=May 1972}}</ref> and chairman of the Pahlavi Foundation.<ref>{{cite web|last=Miri|first=Rozita|title=The Senate|url=http://iichs.org/index_en.asp?img_cat=115&img_type=0|work=IICHS|accessdate=25 July 2013}}</ref><ref name=Lorentz2010>{{cite book|author=John H. Lorentz|title=The A to Z of Iran|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oV9WwxXbCB8C&pg=PA306|accessdate=25 July 2013|date=14 April 2010|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=978-1-4617-3191-7|pages=306}}</ref> He was one of the close confidants of the Shah.<ref name=cia72/>
==Personal life== Sharif-Emami was married and had three children, two daughters and a son.<ref name=saxonyt/>
For some years he was also the [[Grand Master (Masonic)|Grand Master]] of the [[Freemason]] [[Grand Lodge]] of Iran, which gave him some informal influence among Iran's political elite.<ref name="memoirs">[http://ibexpub.com/index.php?main_page=pubs_product_book_info&products_id=89 Memoirs of Sharif-Emami, Prime Minister ]</ref><ref name=milani>{{cite book|author=Abbās Mīlānī|title=Eminent Persians: The Men and Women who Made Modern Iran, 1941 - 1979|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ixU33FaG_dgC&pg=PA305|accessdate=25 July 2013|publisher=Syracuse University Press|isbn=978-0-8156-0907-0|pages=305}}</ref>
==Later years and death== Sharif-Emami left Iran following [[1979 Islamic Revolution|the 1979 Islamic revolution]]. He settled in the [[Upper East Side]] of [[Manhattan]], [[New York City]].<ref name=saxonyt/> There he served as the president of the Pahlavi Foundation and later resigned from the post.<ref name=saxonyt/> He died at a hospital on 16 June 1998 at age 87 in New York City.<ref name=saxonyt>{{cite news|last=Saxon|first=Wolfang|title=Jafar Sharif-Emami, 87, Aide to Shah and a Prime Minister|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/23/world/jafar-sharif-emami-87-aide-to-shah-and-a-prime-minister.html|accessdate=25 July 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=23 June 1998}}</ref> He was buried in [[Valhalla, New York]].<ref name=saxonyt/>

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2011}} {{Infobox person | name = Joe Barza | image = Joe Barza.JPG | image_size = 200px | caption = Joe Barza | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=y|1963|8|11}} | birth_place = [[Tyre, Lebanon]] | death_date = | death_place = | other_names = | occupation = [[chef]], [[television personality]], and culinary consultant | years_active = | children = Karim, Noura | website = {{url|http://www.joebarza.com}} }} '''Joe Barza''' (born 11 August 1963) is a [[Lebanon|Lebanese]] [[chef]], [[television personality]], and culinary consultant. Barza is known for co-hosting the [[Middle East]]ern version of the TV program ''[[Top Chef]]''. ==Early life== Born in [[Tyre, Lebanon]], Barza was first influenced by traditional [[Lebanese cuisine]] as a child in his mother’s kitchen.{{Citation needed|date= May 2018}} Growing up in a war torn country, Barza had no choice but to integrate in one of the many popular [[militia]]s of the time. Barza served as a personal [[bodyguard]] to a personality and major key player in the [[Lebanese Civil War|Lebanese war]], before deciding in 1980 to abandon the life of war, and seek better more sustainable opportunities.{{Citation needed|date= May 2018}} After enlisting at the Hotel School of Arts in Lebanon,Abou Dhabi, Tourism Authority. [http://www.gourmetabudhabi.ae/ad2010/english/masterchef.php?id=24 "Master Chef, Profiles"], ''Gourmet Abu Dhabi'', 18 February 2010, accessed 16 May 2011. Barza graduated in 1982 and immediately immigrated to [[South Africa]], seeking new work opportunities as a chef. ==Early cooking career== Before moving to South Africa, Barza had started his culinary career as a [[commis chef]] (Apprentice Chef)at the "Rimal Beach Resort", and "Le Romarin" Restaurants in Lebanon.{{Citation needed|date= May 2018}} In South Africa, his first job was at [[Johannesburg International Airport]], where he started as a [[Chef de partie|Chef de Partie]], where he quickly progressed in the ranks and within 3 years reached the position of Executive Sous Chef, responsible for serving up to 17,000 meals a day to travelers, and managing a team of 110 kitchen personnel, and 3 [[Sous chef|Sous Chefs]].{{Citation needed|date= May 2018}} ==Head Chef== The Lebanese civil war officially ended in 1990, and three years later in 1993 Barza decided to come back to his home country Lebanon. It is there that Barza was offered his first head chef position at "Century Park Hotel" in [[Jounieh]], Lebanon,Sydney International, Food Festival. [http://www.cravesydneyfoodfestival.com.au/chef.php?intid=157&intversion=12 "Chef, Profiles"], ''Crave Sydney Food Festival'', 10 October 2010, accessed 16 May 2011. Barza was responsible for preparing [[banquet]]s for up to 4,000 people,weekly outside caterings for up to 1,000 people,in charge of 20 permanent chefs, and assuming other hotel positions such as [[hotel manager]] on Duty. Barza stayed with the establishment for eight years, before the hotel changed ownership. His second head chef position came directly afterward, when he was appointed head chef for "The Chase",Slow Food, International. [http://www.slowfood.com/sloweb/eng/dettaglio.lasso?cod=3E6E345B0a4e124E54OUtl31286A "Official Agreement Between Earth Markets in Tuscany and Lebanon to be Signed in Beirut , News"], ''Slow Food News'', 22 April 2009, accessed 16 May 2011. chain of international restaurants, who had up to 9 outlets in Lebanon, and around the world.The Chase, Restaurants. [http://www.chase.com.lb "The Chase Restaurants, Official Website"], ''The Chase Profile'', 1 January 2005, accessed 16 May 2011. After nine years with the establishment, and as the company also changed ownership, Barza decided to end his head chef career, and use the experience he acquired along the years as a culinary consultant.{{Citation needed|date= May 2018}} ==Consultant Chef== In 2010, Barza started his own company, "Joe Barza Culinary Consultancy".Joe Barza, Culinary Consultancy. [http://www.joebarza.com "Official Website of Joe Barza Culinary Consultancy, Profile"], ''Joe Barza Culinary Consultancy'', 26 April 2011, accessed 16 May 2011. The company was to be built around his personal experience and exposure to the different trends and techniques of the culinary world.The company's main scope of work is dealing with all aspects of [[restaurant]] and [[catering]] operations, including concept formulation, menu elaboration, kitchen design, kitchen personnel recruiting, pre-opening strategy formulation, opening strategy formulation, post-opening follow-up, cost control, and staff training. In addition to the corporate services, Barza is a consultant for Salon Culinaire of Lebanon "HORECA".Horeca, Lebanese Salon Culinaire. [http://www.hospitalitynewsmag.com/Library/Files/Uploaded%20Files/Hr11%20Preview-web.pdf "Events Special 2011, News"], ''Horeca Salon Culinaire'', 1 April 2011, accessed 16 May 2011. ==Awards and International Culinary Event Participations== Throughout the years, Barza has amassed a large number of awards and recognitions for his skills and efforts, and has represented Lebanon in a number of worldwide culinary events and forums. Demonstrate Lebanese cuisine at Les Etoiles de MouginsNice Panorama, Joe Barza A Mougins. [http://nice-panorama.com/Mougins/Les-Etoiles-de-Mougins-2008/Joe-Barza/ "Personal Highlight, News"], ''Joe Barza Mougins'', 10 August 2008, accessed 16 May 2011. |- | 2006 || Tuna World Champion at "Girotonno" in Carlo Forte, [[Sardinia]] |- | 2005 || Head of the Lebanese delegation to the "Coupe Du Monde de la Pâtisserie" 5th World Ranking |- | 2003 || Head of the Lebanese delegation to the "Coupe Du Monde de la Pâtisserie" 9th World Ranking + Best Team Spirit "European Sandwich Challenge" Honor prize of the Jury |- | 2000 || [[Beirut]] Salon Culinaire, Gold Medal for the 5 course meal |- | 1999 || Beirut Salon Culinaire, Silver Medal for Gastronomic Group + Silver Medal for Lebanese [[Mezze]] |- | 1997 || Beirut Salon Culinaire, Gold Medal for Team Entry + Bronze Medal for Cold Dish Platter |- | 1996 || Beirut Salon Culinaire, Silver Medal for Sea Food Platter + Silver Medal for Gastronomic Group |- | 1995 || Beirut Salon Culinaire, Silver Medal for Gastronomic Group |} ==Joe Barza SARL== Joe Barza SARL is an [[investment]] front from which new investments in promising restaurants or other food and beverage related products, ideas, or industries are done.{{Citation needed|date= May 2018}} ==Television== Joe Barza has participated and hosted a number of TV shows and programs, the latest being the middle east version of the [[Emmy Award]] winning series "Top Chef". Barza is co-hosting Season One of "Top Chef" with magazine and restaurant owner Siham Tueni.Lebanese Broadcasting Corporation, Episode Highlights. [http://www.lbcfanclub.com/apps/videos/videos/show/13493205-top-chef-episode-1-4 "Episode Highlights, Top Chef"], ''Joe Barza Television'', 28 April 2011, accessed 16 May 2011. Barza was also featured in thirteen episodes of "Sofra Deymeh", on Lebanese channel [[LBCI]], as well as twenty two episodes of "Star Chef" on Saudi channel [[Middle East Broadcasting Center|MBC]], and nine Episodes of "Rotana Café". ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.joebarza.com Personal Website of Joe Barza] *[http://www.insiderei.com/beirut/insider-beirut-joe-barza-the-chase-restaurant-ginette-eau-de-vie-lutecia-phoenicia-hotel-elie-saab-rabih-keyrouz-zadig-et-voltaire Austrian Magazine On Beirut from Joe's Perspective] *[http://www.aidamollenkamp.com/tag/joe-barza/ Food Traveller on Joe Barza] *[http://www.yalibnan.com/2010/06/04/top-chefs-reinventing-lebanese-cuisine-in-beirut/ Top Chefs reinventing Lebanese cuisine in Beirut] *[http://www.abudhabitourism.ae/en/news/lebanese.fusion.taked.centre.stage.at.gourmet.abudhabi.aspx Abu Dhabi Tourism Authority on Joe Barza] *[http://www.sbs.com.au/yourlanguage/arabic/highlight/page/id/121571/t/Chef-Joe-Barza Interview on Australian Radio (In Arabic)] *[http://www.thecakeandtheknife.com/2010/10/bazar-bing-aka-middle-eastern-stream-at.html Barza Bing !] {{DEFAULTSORT:Barza, Joe}} [[Category:Lebanese chefs]] [[Category:Lebanese people]] [[Category:People from Tyre, Lebanon]] [[Category:1963 births]] [[Category:Living people]]

{{Infobox person | name = Kiilh-sooh-kwa | image = File:Kiilhsoohkwa 01.png | caption = Image of Kiilh-sooh-kwa from The Star Press (Muncie, Indiana) on 6 September 1915. | birth_date = 1810 | birth_place = Huntington County, Indiana | death_date = 1915 | death_place = Huntington County, Indiana | resting_place = Glenwood Cemetery (Roanoke, Indiana) | residence = Huntington County, Indiana | other_names = Margaret Revarre | known_for = Granddaughter of Mihšihkinaahkwa. Reportedly cared for the flag presented to her other grandfather at the Treaty of Greenville. }} '''Kiilh-sooh-kwa''' (var. ''Kiilhsoohkwa, Kil-so-quah,'' ''Kilsoquah, Margaret Revarre'') was a member of the [[Miami people|Myaamia Nation]] and granddaughter of [[Little Turtle|Myaamia Chief Mihšihkinaahkwa]] (var. ''Little Turtle'').<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Cottman|first=George S.|date=December 1906|title=Historical Interest in Whitley County|url=|journal=The Indiana Quarterly Magazine of History|publisher=Indiana University Press|volume= 2| issue = 4|pages=200–202}}</ref> She was born in 1810 and died in 1915.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=|title=Kilsoquah Dies At Age Of 105|last=|first=|date=4 September 1915|work=The Fort Wayne News|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|location=Fort Wayne, IN|edition=City; Saturday Evening}}</ref> She was one of the few [[Miami people|Myaamia]] who was not removed from Indiana in 1846.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.in.gov/history/markers/489.htm|title=IHB: Kiilhsoohkwa (Kilsoquah)|website=www.in.gov|language=en|access-date=2017-11-14}}</ref>
== Early life == Kiilh-sooh-kwa was born in 1810 in an area she described in an interview in 1906 as near present-day [[Markle, Indiana|Markle]], [[Huntington County, Indiana|Huntington County]] in northeast [[Indiana]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://archive.org/details/historyofwhitley00kale|title=Kilsoquah|last=Kaler|first=Samuel P.|last2=Maring|first2=R. H.|work=History of Whitley County, Indiana|publisher=B. F. Bowen & Co.|year=1907|isbn=|location=Indianapolis, IN|pages=79–83}}</ref> Separate sources suggest she was born at the [[Forks of the Wabash]], closer to present-day [[Huntington, Indiana|Huntington]], [[Huntington County, Indiana|Huntington County]], [[Indiana]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.in.gov/history/markers/489.htm|title=Dr. Perry G. Moore Affidavit|last=|first=|date=30 August 1923|website=Indiana Historical Bureau|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=14 November 2017}}</ref> She was the granddaughter of [[Little Turtle|Myaamia Chief Mihšihkinaahkwa]] (var. ''Little Turtle''). Her father, Wok-shin-gah (var. ''Crescent Moon'') was [[Little Turtle|Mihšihkinaahkwa]]'s son. Her mother was Nah-wah-kah-mo-kwa (var. ''Snow Woman'').<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|title=Death of Kil-So-Quah, 105, Ends Royal Line Of Miamis|last=|first=|date=6 September 1915|work=The Star Press (Muncie, Indiana)|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
Her first husband was John Owl, the son of Chief John Owl. In 1826, the pair wed in an area referred to as Seek's Village around the [[Eel River (Wabash River)|Eel River]].<ref name=":0" /> John passed away with the first year or two of their marriage. In 1832, Kiilh-sooh-kwa wed Shaw-pe-nom-quah (var. ''Anthony Revarre''), who was of half Native American, half French descent trader. Together Kiilh-sooh-kwa and Shaw-pe-nom-quah had six children, four of whom died in infancy. Her two surviving children were a son, Wa-pe-mung-quah (var. ''Little White Loon, Anthony Revarre, Jr.''), and a daughter, Wan-nog-quan-quah (var. ''Snow, Mist, or Fog; Blowing Snow; Happy Fawn; Mary E. Johnson'').<ref>{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=December 1915|title=Kil-So-Quah, The Last of the Miamis, 1810-1915|url=|journal=Indiana Magazine of History|publisher=Indiana University Press|volume= 11| issue = 4|pages=368–377}}</ref><ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=|title=Kil-So-Quah, Age 105, Dying|last=|first=|date=9 September 1915|work=The Waterloo Press (Waterloo, Indiana)|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite book|title=Little Turtle (Me-she-kin-no-quah): The Great Chief of the Miami Indian Nation; Being a Sketch of His Life, Together with that of William Wells and Some Noted Descendants|last=Young|first=Calvin M.|publisher=Sentinel Ptg. Company|year=1917|isbn=|location=Digitized by Google|pages=215}}</ref>
== Later life == Little is documented of her young adult life, though in 2013 she was described by the [[Smithsonian Institution]] as an important midwife in Indiana who understood and used plant knowledge related to childbirth.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://blog.nmai.si.edu/main/2013/09/not-the-last-of-the-miamis.html|title=Not the "Last of the Miamis"|website=blog.nmai.si.edu|access-date=2017-11-14}}</ref> In her later years, she lived in [[Roanoke, Indiana]] on but forty acres of what remained of her family's and her nation's territory.<ref>{{Cite news|title=The Last Of The Miamis|last=Henderson Wheelock|first=Matilda|date=22 August 1909|work=The Star Press (Muncie, Indiana), Sunday Edition|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> She only spoke in her native language despite some sources suggested she understood some English.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":0" /> One of the few English words that she knew and used frequently was "[[rheumatism]]," given her affliction with the disease.<ref name=":3" /> She was described in 1905 as "a big woman, of swarthy appearance, and...a devotee of the pipe, which she has with her almost incessantly" and, separately, was described as a devout Catholic.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Indiana's Only Princess|last=|first=|date=8 November 1905|work=The Elwood Daily Record (Elwood, IN)|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Paleface Tribute Makes Squaw Glad – Kil-So-Quah Excited Over One Hundredth Birthday Celebration at Roanoke Today – 20,000 People Expected|last=|first=|date=4 July 1910|work=The Indianapolis Start (Indianapolis, Indiana)|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
In 1915, a Fort Wayne-based newspaper reported that, "if a stranger called, the old woman would grasp the hand and give a firm grip, and after looking you over would in her quaint way and feeble voice mutter a few words in her native tongue, that if interpreted would be a hearty welcome."<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /> An estimated 15,000 attendees celebrated her 100th birthday in Roanoke and her centennial was well-documented in Indiana newspapers.<ref>{{Cite news|url=|title=Kilsoquah Centennial|last=|first=|date=7 July 1910|work=The Weekly Republican (Plymouth, Indiana)|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> [[File:Kilsoquah Historic Sign Roanoke Indiana Glenwood Cemetery 02.jpg|thumb|Historic sign at Glenwood Cemetery in Roanoke, IN commemorating and memorializing Kiilhsoohkwa.]] [[File:Kilsoquah Historic Sign Roanoke Indiana Glenwood Cemetery 01.jpg|thumb|Historic sign (reverse) at Glenwood Cemetery in Roanoke, IN commemorating and memorializing Kiilhsoohkwa.]] [[File:Kilsoquah Headstone Roanoke Indiana Glenwood Cemetery 03.jpg|thumb|Headstone at Glenwood Cemetery in Roanoke, IN commemorating and memorializing Kiilhsoohkwa.]] She passed away on 4 September 1915 at her home in Roanoke after spending a few weeks ill and confined to her bed. Her death was described as "without a struggle, for death was only a break in the well worn thread of life."<ref name=":3" /> Her passing was characterized in 1917 as a loss of "the last royal Miamis and the oldest resident of the State of Indiana, who had enjoyed a national reputation."<ref name=":3" /> Her funeral services were held at St. James Catholic Church in Roanoke and she was buried in the I.O.O.F. Cemetery (Glenwood Cemetery) in Roanoke.<ref name=":3" /> [[File:Kiilhsoohkwa 02.jpg|thumb|Kiilh-sooh-kwa and her son, 1910 by L. M. Huffman. Courtesy of Smithsonian Institution National Museum of the American Indian.]] [[File:Kiilhsoohkwa 04.png|thumb|Kiilh-sooh-kwa in June 1913 with her son and her daughter. Originally printed in 1917 in ''Little Turtle (Me-she-kin-no-quah): The Great Chief of the Miami Indian Nations'' by C. M. Young.]]
