Steiner (1997), pp 144–5, (Henry Gravrand, "La civilisation Sereer -Pangool" [in]) {{ISBN|3515028420}} *Bressers, Hans, Rosenbaum, Walter A., Achieving sustainable development: the challenge of governance across social scales, Greenwood Publishing Group, (2003) p. 151 {{ISBN|0275978028}} *Niang, Mor Sadio, "CEREMONIES ET FÊTES TRADITIONNELLES", [in] Ethiopiques n<sup>o</sup> 31 révue socialiste de culture négro-africaine 3e trimestre (1982) [http://ethiopiques.refer.sn/spip.php?article905] *Martin, Victor & Becker, Charles, "Lieux de culte et emplacements célèbres dans les pays sereer" (Sénégal), Publié dans le Bulletin de l’[[Institut Fondamental d'Afrique Noire]], Tome 41, Série B, n° 1, janvier 1979, p. 133–189 (p 15) [http://ucadao.s3.amazonaws.com/agorae/2009311111736/V.Martin(a).pdf] *R. P. Crétois, Dictionnaire Sereer-Français, Dakar, CLAD, t. 1 (1972), t. 2 (1973), t. 3 (1974), t. 4 (1975), t. 5 (1976), t. 6 (1977), passim. [in] Martin, Victor & Becker, Charles, "Lieux de culte et emplacements célèbres dans les pays sereer" *Abbé L. Diouf, L’homme dans le monde (Vision sereer), communication aux Journées Africaines de Théologie, polygraphié, s. d., p. 6. [in] Martin, Victor & Becker, Charles, "Lieux de culte et emplacements célèbres dans les pays sereer" *[[Alioune Sarr|Sarr, Alioune]], "[[Alioune Sarr#Histoire du Sine-Saloum|Histoire du Sine-Saloum]]" (Sénégal), Introduction, bibliographie et notes par Charles Becker. Version légèrement remaniée par rapport à celle qui est parue en 1986–87. p 19 *Diouf, Niokhobaye, "Chronique du royaume du Sine", Suivie de notes sur les traditions orales et les sources écrites concernant le royaume du Sine par Charles Becker et Victor Martin. {{More citations needed|date=December 2010}} {{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians --> | name = Paul Williams | image = Paul Williams of the Temptations on Ed Sullivan Show.jpg | caption = Williams performs with The Temptations on ''[[The Ed Sullivan Show]]'' | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date|1939|7|2}} |birth_place =[[Ensley (Birmingham)|Ensley, Alabama]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|1973|8|17|1939|7|2}} |death_place =[[Detroit|Detroit, Michigan]], U.S. | origin = [[Birmingham, Alabama]], U.S. | instrument = {{flatlist| *[[Vocals]] *[[guitar]] }} | genre = {{flatlist| *[[Rhythm and blues|R&B]] *[[Soul music|soul]] }} | occupation = {{flatlist| *Singer *choreographer }} | years_active = 1955–1971 | label = [[Motown]] | associated_acts = {{flatlist| *The Primes *[[The Temptations]] }} }}
'''Paul Williams''' (July 2, 1939 – August 17, 1973) was an American [[baritone]] singer and [[choreographer]]. Williams was noted for being one of the founding members and original [[lead singer]] of the [[Motown]] group [[The Temptations]]. Along with [[Elbridge "Al" Bryant]], [[Otis Williams]] , and fellow Alabamians [[Eddie Kendricks]] and [[Melvin Franklin]], Williams was a member of The Temptations during the "Classic Five" period. Personal problems and failing health forced Williams to retire in 1971. He was found dead two years later as the result of an apparent suicide.
==Early years== Paul Williams was born and raised in the [[Ensley (Birmingham)|Ensley]] neighborhood of [[Birmingham, Alabama]].<ref name="williamsbirth">Ribowsky, Mark (2010). ''Ain't Too Proud to Beg: The Troubled Lives and Enduring Soul of the Temptations''. Hoboken, New Jersey: John Wiley & Sons. {{ISBN|978-0-470-26117-0}}. Pg. 9-14</ref> He was the son of Sophia and Rufus Williams, a gospel singer in a gospel music vocal group called the Ensley Jubilee Singers.<ref name="williamsbirth" /> He met [[Eddie Kendricks]] in elementary school; supposedly, the two first encountered each other in a fistfight after Williams dumped a bucket of mop water on Kendricks.<ref name="williamsbirth" /> Both boys shared a love of singing, and sang in their church choir together.<ref name="williamsbirth" /> As teenagers, Williams, Kendricks, and [[Kell Osborne]] and Willie Waller performed in a secular singing group known as The Cavaliers, with dreams of making it big in the music industry. In 1957, Williams, Kendricks, and Osborne left Birmingham to start careers, leaving Waller behind. Now known as The Primes, the trio moved to [[Cleveland, Ohio]], and eventually found a manager in Milton Jenkins, who moved the group to [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]]. Although The Primes never recorded, they were successful performers, and even launched a spin-off female group called The Primettes, who later became [[The Supremes]].
In 1961, Kell Osborne moved to [[California]], and the Primes disbanded. Kendricks returned to Alabama, but visited Paul in Detroit shortly after. While on this visit, he and Paul had learned that [[Otis Williams]], head of a rival Detroit act known as The Distants, had two openings in his group's lineup. Paul Williams and Kendricks joined Otis Williams, [[Melvin Franklin]], and [[Elbridge Bryant]] to form The Elgins, who signed to the local [[Motown]] label in 1961, after first changing their name to [[The Temptations]].
==With the Temptations== {{main|The Temptations}} Although the group now had a record deal, Paul Williams and his bandmates endured a long series of failed singles before finally hitting the [[Billboard magazine|Billboard]] Top 20 in 1964 with "[[The Way You Do the Things You Do]]." More hits quickly followed, including "[[My Girl (The Temptations song)|My Girl]]", "[[Ain't Too Proud To Beg]]" and "[[(I Know) I'm Losing You]]."
Williams sang lead on several of the group's songs, and served as the main lead singer during the group's early years. His early leads include, "Your Wonderful Love" (1961), "Slow Down Heart" (1962), "[[I Want a Love I Can See]]" (1963), and "[[Oh Mother of Mine|Oh, Mother of Mine]]" (1961) (the group's first single) and "[[Farewell My Love]]" (1963) both shared with Eddie Kendricks. Considered the Temptations' best dancer, Williams served as the group's original [[choreographer]], devising routines for his group and [[The Supremes]] (most notably their trademark "[[Stop! In the Name of Love]]" routine), before [[Cholly Atkins]] took over that role for all of Motown's acts. Williams' later leads on Temptations songs include, "Just Another Lonely Night" (1965), "No More Water in the Well" (1967), a cover version of "[[Hey Girl (Freddie Scott song)|Hey Girl]]" (1969), and his signature song "[[Don't Look Back (The Temptations song)|Don't Look Back]]" (1965).
Williams also sang lead with Dennis Edwards, who joined in 1968, on Motown's first Grammy Award-Winner "[[Cloud Nine (The Temptations song)|Cloud Nine]]". One of his best-known lead performances is his stand out live performance of "[[For Once in My Life]]," from the [[television]] special ''[[TCB (television special)|TCB]]'', originally broadcast on December 9, 1968 on [[NBC]]. The live version of the song "Don't Look Back" is also frequently cited as one of his standout performances. He also took over the lead vocal for live performances of "[[My Girl (The Temptations song)|My Girl]]" following [[David Ruffin]]'s departure from the group.
==Personal problems and decline== Williams suffered from [[sickle-cell anemia]], which frequently wrought havoc on his physical health. In 1965, Williams began an affair with Winnie Brown, hair stylist for [[The Supremes]] and a relative of Supremes member [[Florence Ballard]]. In love with Brown but still devoted to his wife and children, Williams was also [[Major depressive disorder|depressed]] because [[Cholly Atkins]]' presence now made Williams' former role as choreographer essentially, but not completely, obsolete. Life on the road was starting to take its toll on Williams as well, and, having previously consumed nothing stronger than [[milk]], he began to [[alcoholism|drink alcohol heavily]], namely [[Courvoisier]], which, according to [[Otis Williams]], was hard to take.<ref>http://www.deseretnews.com/article/660060/Tale-of-the-Temptations.html?pg=all</ref>
In the spring of 1969, Williams and Brown opened a celebrity fashion [[boutique]] in downtown Detroit. The business was not as successful as planned, and Williams soon found himself owing more than [[USD|$]]80,000 in taxes (US${{formatnum:{{Inflation|US|80000|1969}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}). His health had deteriorated to the point that he would sometimes be unable to perform, suffering from combinations of exhaustion and pain which he combated with heavy drinking. Each of the other four Temptations did what they could to help Williams, alternating between raiding and draining his alcohol stashes, personal [[intervention (counseling)|interventions]], and keeping [[oxygen tank]]s backstage, but Williams' health, as well as the quality of his performances, continued to decline and he refused to see a doctor.
Otis Williams and the other Temptations decided to resort to enlisting an on-hand fill-in for Paul Williams. [[Richard Street]], then-lead singer of fellow Motown act [[The Monitors (American band)|The Monitors]] and formerly lead singer of The Distants, was hired to travel with The Temptations and sing all of Williams' parts, save for Williams' special numbers such as "Don't Look Back" and "For Once in My Life", from backstage behind a curtain. When Williams was not well enough to go on, Street took his place onstage. In April 1971, Williams was finally persuaded to go see a doctor. The doctor found a [[Cirrhosis|spot]] on Williams' [[liver]] and advised him to retire from the group altogether. Williams left the group and Street became his permanent replacement. In support of helping Williams get back on his feet, The Temptations continued to pay Williams his same one-fifth share of the group's earnings, and kept Williams on their payroll as an advisor and choreographer, and Williams continued to help the group with routines and dance moves for the next two years.
==Later years== By early 1973, Williams made his return to Motown's [[Hitsville USA]] recording studios, and began working on solo material. Kendricks, who had quit the Temptations just before Williams left, produced and co-[[songwriter|wrote]] Williams' first single, "Feel Like Givin' Up", which was to have been issued on Motown's Gordy imprint with "Once You Had a Heart" as its [[b-side]]. However, after Williams' death was ruled a suicide in August 1973, Motown decided to shelve the sides, because the song "Feel Like Givin' Up" was just too literal to bear and the single was not released.
==Death== On August 17, 1973,<ref>{{cite web|url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=the temptations|bio=true}}|title=Artist Biography — The Temptations|last=Ankeny|first=Jason|work=All Music Guide|accessdate=10 April 2009}}</ref> Paul Williams was found dead in an alley in a car having just left the new house of his then-girlfriend after an argument.<ref name="williamsdeath" /> A gun was found near his body. His death was ruled a suicide by the coroner; Williams had expressed suicidal thoughts to Otis Williams and Melvin Franklin months before his death.<ref name="williamsdeath">Ribowsky, Mark (2010). ''Ain't Too Proud to Beg: The Troubled Lives and Enduring Soul of the Temptations''. Hoboken, New Jersey: John Wiley & Sons. {{ISBN|978-0-470-26117-0}}. Pg. 237-248</ref>
Williams' funeral was held on August 24, with his family and former bandmates in attendance. He was survived by his wife, Mary Agnes Williams, and five children: Sarita, Kenneth, Paula, Mary and Paul Jr. Paul Jr later joined a Temptations splinter group, The Temptations Review featuring Dennis Edwards. Williams also had three other children, Paul Williams Lucas, Anthony Johnson, and Derrick Vinyard, with three girlfriends.<ref name="williamsdeath2">{{cite web| author=Snell, Robert | date=June 25, 2011 | title=''Temptations heir sues sister over lost royalties''. | url=http://www.estateofdenial.com/2011/06/28/temptations-heir-sues-sister-over-lost-royalties-mi/ | publisher=''The Detroit News''}}</ref> Williams is buried at Lincoln Memorial Park Cemetery, Clinton Township, Macomb County, Michigan in Lot 275, Grave #4, Section #G.
The circumstances surrounding Williams' death caused the Williams family to suspect that some form of foul play was the actual cause of Williams' death.<ref name="williamsdeath" /> According to the coroner, Williams had used his right hand to shoot himself on the left side of his head.<ref name="williamsdeath" /> In addition, a bottle of alcohol was found near Williams' left side, as if he had dropped it while being shot. The gun used in the shooting was found to have fired two shots, only one of which had killed Williams.<ref name="williamsdeath" />
==Legacy== As a member of the Temptations, Paul Williams was posthumously inducted into the [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame]] in 1989 and the [[Vocal Group Hall of Fame]] in 1999 and the Rhythm & Blues Music Hall of Fame in 2013. Both of his solo recordings were later released by Motown on Temptations-related compilations in the 1980s and 1990s.
In 1998, [[NBC]] aired ''[[The Temptations (TV miniseries)|The Temptations]]'', a four-hour television miniseries based upon an autobiographical book by Otis Williams. Paul Williams was portrayed by actor [[Christian Payton]].
The music video for the [[Diana Ross]] song "Missing You" pays tribute to [[Marvin Gaye]], Florence Ballard, and Paul Williams, all former Motown artists who had died.
==Complete lead vocals with the Temptations== {{organize-section|date=September 2017}} <!--can we make this look like the corresponding section of [[David Ruffin discography]]?--> Paul Williams' vocals were featured on the following Temptations songs: {{col-begin}} {{col-break}}
* [[Cloud Nine (The Temptations song)|Cloud Nine]] * [[Runaway Child, Running Wild]] * Hey Girl (solo) * Lonely, Lonely Man Am I (solo) * Who You Gonna Run To (solo) * [[Hello, Young Lovers (song)|Hello, Young Lovers]] * [[Just Another Lonely Night]] (solo) * [[For Once in My Life]] (solo) * [[Who Can I Turn To]] (solo) {{col-break}}
* [[That's Life (song)|That's Life]] (solo) * No More Water In The Well (solo) * [[I Want a Love I Can See]] (solo) * [[Isn't She Pretty]] * [[Just Let Me Know]] (solo) * Your Wonderful Love (solo) * The Further You Look, the Less You See (solo) * [[Check Yourself]] (solo) * Slow Down Heart (solo) * [[Farewell My Love]] * Oh, Mother of Mine (solo) * Romance Without Finance (solo) {{col-break}}
* [[Psychedelic Shack (song)|Psychedelic Shack]] * [[War (The Temptations song)|War]] * [[I Can't Get Next To You]] * [[Don't Look Back (The Temptations song)|Don't Look Back]] (solo) * [[Hey Jude]] * Don't Let the Joneses Get You Down * [[Little Green Apples]] (solo) * Running Away (Ain't Gonna Help You)(solo) * [[Just My Imagination (Running Away With Me)]] * [[Baby, Baby I Need You]] * [[You Beat Me To The Punch]] (solo) * [[Gonna Give Her All the Love I've Got]] (solo) * No Man Can Love Her Like I Do (solo) {{col-end}} * [[The Way You Do The Things You Do]]

{{refimprove|date=November 2009}}{{Expand German|date=November 2018}} '''Pierre Jaquet-Droz''' ({{IPA-fr|ʒakɛ dʁo|lang}}; 1721–1790) was a [[watchmaker]] of the late eighteenth century. He lived in [[Paris]], [[London]], and [[Geneva]], where he designed and built animated dolls, or [[automata]], to help his firm sell watches and mechanical birds. ==Notable works== [[File:Automates-Jaquet-Droz-p1030472.jpg|thumb|The [[Jaquet-Droz automata]]]] Constructed between 1768 and 1774 by Pierre Jaquet-Droz, his son Henri-Louis (1752-1791), and Jean-Frédéric Leschot (1746-1824), the automata include ''The Writer'' (made of 6000 pieces), ''The Musician'' (2500 pieces), and ''The Draughtsman'' (2000 pieces). His astonishing mechanisms fascinated the kings and emperors of Europe, China, India, and Japan. Some consider these devices to be the oldest examples of the [[computer]]. ''The Writer'', a mechanical boy who writes with a quill pen upon paper with real ink, has an input device to set tabs, defining individual letters written by the boy, that form a programmable memory. It has 40 cams that represent the read-only programme. The work of Pierre Jaquet-Droz predates that of [[Charles Babbage]] by decades. The automata of Jaquet-Droz are considered to be some of the finest examples of human mechanical problem solving. Three particularly complex and still functional dolls, now known as the [[Jaquet-Droz automata]], are housed at the [[Musée d'Art et d'Histoire (Neuchâtel)|Musée d'Art et d'Histoire]] (art and history museum) in [[Neuchâtel, Switzerland]]. He once constructed a clock that was capable of the following surprising movements:
There were seen on it a negro, a dog, and a shepherd; when the clock struck, the shepherd played six tunes on his flute, and the dog approached and fawned upon him. This clock was exhibited to the King of Spain, who was delighted with it. "The gentleness of my dog," said Droz, "is his least merit; if your Majesty touch one of the apples, which you see in the shepherd's basket, you will admire the fidelity of this animal." The King took an apple, and the dog flew at his hand, and barked so loud, that the King's dog, which was in the room, began also to bark; at this the Courtiers, not doubting that it was an affair of witchcraft, hastily left the room, crossing themselves as they went out. The minister of Marine was the only one that ventured to stay. The king having desired him to ask the negro what o'clock it was, the minister obeyed, but he obtained no reply. Droz then observed, that the negro had not yet learned Spanish.{{cite web|url=http://www.gutenberg.org/dirs/1/1/3/8/11384/11384-h/11384-h.htm |title=The Project Gutenberg eBook of "The Mirror of Literature, Amusement, and Instruction", Vol. 10, Issue 275, September 29, 1827, by Various |publisher=Gutenberg.org |date=2004-03-01 |accessdate=2013-05-19}}

Les automates Jaquet-Droz'', Lausanne, 1979 *Beaune, Jean-Claude, ''L'automate et ses mobiles'', Paris, 1980 *Tissot, André, ''Voyage de Pierre Jaquet-Droz à la Cour du Roi d'Espagne 1758-1759'', Neuchâtel, 1982 *Beyer, Annette,'' Faszienierende Welt der Automaten'', Munich, 1983 *Collectif, ''The Cyborg Handbook'', London, 1995 *Vanden Berghe, Marc, ''Henri-Louis Jaquet-Droz'' et ''Pierre Jaquet-Droz'' in ''Biographies Neuchâteloises'', tome I, *Hauterive, Attinger, 1996 *Collectif, ''Die Androïden: zur Poetologie des Automaten'', Bern, Peter Lang, 1996 (contributions in German en French. {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2015}} {{Use British English|date=July 2015}} {{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians --> | name = Richard Hughes | image = Richard Hughes Keane 2009 - 1.jpg | caption = | background = non_vocal_instrumentalist | birth_name = Richard David Hughes | Aliases = Rich Hughes | birth_date ={{birth date and age|df=yes|1975|9|8}} |birth_place =[[Gravesend, Kent|Gravesend]], [[Kent]], [[England]] | instrument = [[Drum kit|Drums]], [[Backing vocalist|backing vocals]] | genre = [[Alternative rock]] | occupation = [[Drummer]] | years_active = 1995–present | Labels = | associated_acts = [[Keane (band)|Keane]] }} '''Richard David Hughes''' (born 8 September 1975, [[Gravesend, Kent|Gravesend]], [[Kent]]) is an English [[musician]], best known as the [[drummer]] of the British pop rock band [[Keane (band)|Keane]].
== Biography == Richard David Hughes attended [[Tonbridge School]] where he was friends with future Keane members [[Tim Rice-Oxley]] and [[Dominic Scott]]. At the age of 17, Hughes learned to play the drums, and when Scott and Rice-Oxley formed a small [[cover version|covers]] band in 1995 he was invited to join as drummer. They later invited future lead singer [[Tom Chaplin]] to join the band, although Hughes initially objected, later stating, "The idea of giving someone who's already the loudest person you know a microphone was not something that I was particularly keen on."
Hughes then went to university at [[University College London]] where he received a [[academic degree|degree]] in [[Geography]]. He took a job as a [[secretary]] at the [[BBC]] in order to support himself and the band while they lived and practiced in a flat on Upper Clapton Road in [[London]]. He also had a job as a [[supply teacher]] for a short time. It has been said that the song 'Put it Behind You' was written by Rice-Oxley for Hughes after he had broken up with a girlfriend, and that much of the album 'Perfect Symmetry' - in particular the track 'You Don't See Me' - was also written about him and his unrequited love for a music journalist who broke his heart by marrying another man. Hughes is known to be the most humorous member of the band. Since ''[[Under the Iron Sea]]'' was released he has provided additional backing vocals for the band. He was married, presumably to his long-time girlfriend, in 2010.
He is a [[Human rights activist|Human Rights activist]] with [[Amnesty International]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.amnesty.org.uk/blogs_entry.asp?eid=3808 |title=Amnesty Blogs: Press release me, let me go : Death row records: Richard Hughes and Troy Davis |publisher=Blogs.amnesty.org.uk |date=2009-09-25 |accessdate=2011-10-18}}</ref> On 3 November 2011 Hughes spoke at the [[Oxford Union]] about his work with [[Amnesty International]], and his campaign for justice for [[Troy Davis]].
== Personal life == {{BLP sources|date=January 2017}} Hughes collects "Nikon" brand cameras and calls himself "Nikon Guy". He is a great lover of photography and updates the site [[Keane (band)|Keane]] with "photoblogs" with photographs of the band on tour. He is a fan of the Irish rock band [[U2]], and other bands and groups like [[The Smiths]], [[The Beatles]] and [[Björk]]. His favorite song from the album ''[[Hopes and Fears]]'' is "[[Bend and Break]]" and "Put It Behind You" from [[Under the Iron Sea]]. Hughes is [[colourblind]] to green and brown, as said in a video where Richard answers 50 fan questions (can be found on the band's YouTube channel.)
==Equipment== Hughes uses Yamaha drums, [[Zildjian]] cymbals and [[Vic Firth]] drumsticks. He also used [[Sabian]] cymbals in the past.
Drums: Yamaha absolute maple
Cymbals: Zildjian: * 14" A Custom hi-hats * 18" A Custom projection crash * 18" ZBT crash/ride * 19" K dark crash thin * 21" K crash/ride * 21" A sweet ride
==Supports and foundations== Keane took the initiative to participate in [[War Child (charity)|War Child]] (foundation to help children in countries at war). Richard is an activist who defends human rights, together with Amnesty International. He is also very involved in the case of [[Troy Davis]], sometimes wearing T-shirts with the message "I am Troy Davis" during his tour in the [[United States]]. Richard is also a great animal advocate and has been a vegetarian since age 13.
==Discography==
===with Keane=== {{Main article|Keane discography}} {{col-begin}} {{col-break}} ;Studio albums :* ''[[Hopes and Fears]]'' (2004) :* ''[[Under the Iron Sea]]'' (2006) :* ''[[Perfect Symmetry (Keane album)|Perfect Symmetry]]'' (2008) :* ''[[Strangeland (album)|Strangeland]]'' (2012) {{col-break}} ;EPs :* ''[[Retrospective EPs#Everybody's Changing|Retrospective EP1]]'' (2008) :* ''[[Night Train (EP)|Night Train]]'' (2010) :* ''[[Retrospective EPs#Sunshine|Retrospective EP2]]'' (2010) ;Compilations album :* ''[[The Best of Keane]]'' (2013) {{col-end}}

[[File:Samira Ibrahim - سميرة ابراهيم.jpg|thumb|Graffiti reproducing Samira Ibrahim's face.]] '''Samira Ibrahim''' ({{lang-ar|سميرة إبراهيم}}, {{IPA-arz|sæˈmiːɾæ ebɾˤɑˈhiːm|IPA}}) (born [[circa|c.]] 1987) is an [[Egypt]]ian activist who came to prominence during the Egyptian revolution.
==Tahrir sit-in and aftermath== On March 9, 2011, she participated in a sit-in at [[Tahrir Square]] in [[Cairo]]. The military violently dispersed protest participants, and Samira and other women were beaten, given electric shocks, [[strip search]]ed, and videotaped by the soldiers. They were also subjected to [[virginity test]]s. The tests were allegedly carried out to protect the soldiers from claims of rape.
After succeeding in placing the case in front of a civilian court, a [[court order]] was issued in December 2011 to stop the practice of “virginity tests”. However, in March 2012, a [[military court]] [[exonerated]] Dr. Adel El Mogy from charges laid in connection with the virginity testing of Ibrahim.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/opinion/2012/03/2012316133129201850.html |title=What made her go there? Samira Ibrahim and Egypt's virginity test trial |publisher=Aljazeera.com |date= |accessdate=2013-05-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/03/11/ahmed-adel-virginity-test-doctor_n_1337392.html |title=Ahmed Adel, Egyptian Military 'Virginity Test' Doctor, Acquitted |publisher=Huffingtonpost.com |date= March 11, 2012|accessdate=2013-05-19 |first=Ryan |last=Craggs}}</ref><ref>[http://content.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2111975_2111976_2111959,00.html The World's 100 Most Influential People: 2012 - Samira Ibrahim] by Charlize Theron, ''[[Time Magazine]]'', Wednesday, April 18, 2012.</ref>
Ibrahim vowed to take her case to the international courts.<ref>{{cite news|author=Abdel-Rahman Hussein in Cairo |url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2012/mar/13/women-samira-ibrahim-egypt-virginity-tests/print |title='The future of Egyptian women is in danger' - Samira Ibrahim speaks out |publisher=Guardian |date= March 13, 2012|accessdate=2013-05-19 |location=London}}</ref>
==2013 Twitter allegations== In early March 2013, Ibrahim came under criticism after [[Samuel Tadros]], writing in ''[[The Weekly Standard]]'', accused her of posting [[anti-Semitic]] and [[anti-American]] statements on her [[Twitter]] account. These statements included quoting [[Adolf Hitler]], writing: "I have discovered with the passage of days, that no act contrary to morality, no crime against society, takes place, except with the Jews having a hand in it. Hitler.” In reaction to a [[2012 Burgas bus bombing|suicide bombing]] of a bus of Israelis in Bulgaria, she wrote "Today is a very sweet day with a lot of very sweet news.”<ref name=Weeklystandard>{{cite news |url=http://www.weeklystandard.com/blogs/michelle-obama-and-john-kerry-honor-anti-semite-and-911-fan_706547.html |archive-url=https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20130324130812/http://www.weeklystandard.com/blogs/michelle-obama-and-john-kerry-honor-anti-semite-and-911-fan_706547.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=March 24, 2013 |title=Michelle Obama and John Kerry to Honor Anti-Semite and 9/11 Fan |newspaper=Weekly Standard |author=Samuel Tadros |date=March 6, 2013 |df= }}</ref> In 2012 on the anniversary of the [[September 11 terrorist attack]]s, she tweeted "Today is the anniversary of [[9/11]]. May every year come with America burning".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://foxnewsinsider.com/2013/03/07/michelle-malkin-takes-on-state-department-for-honoring-samira-ibrahim-woman-who-praised-911/ |title=Michelle Malkin Takes on State Department for Honoring Samira Ibrahim, Woman Who Praised 9/11 |publisher=[[Fox News]] |date= March 7, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/activist-samira-ibrahim-denied-international-women-of-courage-prize-over-antius-tweets/1085035/1 |title=Activist Samira Ibrahim denied International Women of Courage prize over anti-US tweets |publisher= [[Associated Press]] (reprinted in ''The Indian Express'') |date=March 8, 2013}}</ref><ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/worldviews/wp/2013/03/08/the-tweets-that-cost-samira-ibrahim-her-state-department-award/ The tweets that cost Samira Ibrahim her State Department award] by Caitlin Dewey, ''[[Washington Post]]'', March 8, 2013.</ref>
The American State Department subsequently announced that it will not be giving the ''International Women of Courage Award'' to her in light of these comments.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/us-reverses-decision-to-honor-egyptian-woman-activist-in-light-of-anti-us-anti-semitic-tweets/2013/03/07/e3d3b8dc-875b-11e2-a80b-3edc779b676f_story.html|title=US postpones award to honor Egyptian woman activist in light of anti-US, anti-Semitic tweets|newspaper=Washington Post|agency=Associated Press}} {{Dead link|date=April 2014|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4354101,00.html |title=US revokes award for Egyptian woman due to tweets |publisher= Ynetnews.com |date= 8 March 2012 |accessdate= 8 March 2012}}</ref>
Initially, Ibrahim claimed that her Twitter account had been "previously stolen" and that "any tweet on racism and hatred is not me”.<ref name=Weeklystandard/> However, she later stated "I refuse to apologize to the [[Zionist]] lobby in America regarding my previous anti-Zionist statements under pressure from American government therefore they withdrew the award."<ref>[https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2013/03/samira-ibrahim-refuses-to-apologize-for-her-tweets/273835/ Samira Ibrahim 'Refuses to Apologize' for Her Tweets] by [[Jeffrey Goldberg]], ''[[The Atlantic]]'', March 7, 2013.</ref> The U.S. State Department later stated that Ibrahim had since left the United States to return to Egypt.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jta.org/news/article/2013/03/08/3121521/samira-ibrahim-acknowledges-anti-zionist-treat |title=Samira Ibrahim acknowledges ‘anti-Zionist’ tweet |publisher=''[[Jewish Telegraphic Agency]]'' (JTA) |date=March 8, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130311104322/http://www.jta.org/news/article/2013/03/08/3121521/samira-ibrahim-acknowledges-anti-zionist-treat |archivedate=March 11, 2013 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.snopes.com/politics/kerry/ibrahim.asp |title=Samira Ibrahim |publisher= Snopes.com}}</ref>
On March 8, 2013, a spokeswoman for the U.S. State Department stated that "Upon further review, the department has decided not to present her with the award" as American officials "didn't consider some of the public statements that she had made appropriate. They didn't comport with our values" while adding that "There were obviously some problems in our review process, and we're going to do some forensics on how that happened."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.egyptindependent.com/news/us-cancels-award-samira-ibrahim-after-incendiary-tweets |title=US cancels award for Samira Ibrahim after incendiary tweets |publisher=[[Al-masry Al-youm|Egypt Independent]] |date= March 9, 2013}}</ref>
== Awards and recognitions == * Rank 20, [[2012 Time 100]]
==See also== {{Portal|Egypt|Biography}} * [[Human rights in Egypt under the Supreme Council of the Armed Forces]]

revision.text:
{{all plot|date=October 2014}} {{Infobox comics character| |image= msmarvel2.jpg |image_size= 250 |caption= Sharon Ventura makes her first appearance as the new Ms. Marvel. From ''The Thing'' #35 (May 1986). Art by [[Paul Neary]]. |character_name= Sharon Ventura |real_name= Sharon Ventura |publisher= [[Marvel Comics]] |debut= ''[[Thing (comics)|The Thing]]'' #27 (September 1985) |creators= [[Mike Carlin]]
[[Ron Wilson (comics)|Ron Wilson]] |alliances=[[Grapplers (comics)|Grapplers]]
[[Thunderiders]]
[[Fantastic Four]]
[[Frightful Four]] |aliases= Ms. Marvel, She-Thing |powers=Highly proficient hand to hand combatant
Skilled martial artist
Expert stuntwoman, scuba diver, skydiver, motorcyclist, mountain climber, skier, lion tamer and wrestler
'''As Ms. Marvel:'''
Superhuman strength and endurance
'''As She-Thing:'''
Superhuman strength, durability and endurance
Rock-like skin }} '''Sharon Ventura''', also known as '''She-Thing''', is a [[fictional character]] appearing in [[American comic book]]s published by [[Marvel Comics]]. She has used the pseudonym [[Ms. Marvel]] and has served as a member of the [[Fantastic Four]] and the female wrestlers known as the [[Grapplers (comics)|Grapplers]]. ==Publication history== {{expand-section|date=October 2014}} Created by [[Mike Carlin]] and [[Ron Wilson (comics)|Ron Wilson]], the character first appeared in ''[[Thing (comics)|Thing]]'' #27 (September 1985). ==Fictional character biography== [[File:SheThing.jpg|thumb|150px|left|Sharon Ventura (as the She-Thing) battles the Fantastic Four. From ''[[Fantastic Four (comic book)|Fantastic Four]]'' #379.]] Sharon Ventura met [[Thing (comics)|Thing]] at the time when he was involved with the [[Unlimited Class Wrestling Federation]] (UCWF).''The Thing'' #27 Inspired by him, she signed up for the [[Power Broker]]'s program in order to have her strength augmented and join the UCWF. The Power Broker (actually Curtiss Jackson), employed Dr. [[Karl Malus]] to create super-powered wrestlers for his competitions. Sharon was unaware of the criminal activities of Jackson or Malus. While boosting their subjects' strength, the pair addicted the subjects to a drug, ensuring their obedience. It has been implied that she was raped while a prisoner of Malus, which caused her to temporarily develop an intense hatred and distrust of men. Sharon managed to break free before Malus administered the drug. She adopted the costume which UCWF minder Ann Fraley ([[Auntie Freeze]]) had arranged for her, taking the name '''Ms. Marvel'''. Alongside the Thing, she battled the [[Grapplers (comics)|Grapplers]] and the UCWF wrestlers.''The Thing'' #35 She then battled the [[She-Hulk]].''The Thing'' #36 Later, Sharon was used by the Power Broker to determine if the augmentation could be reversed.''Captain America'' #330 Alongside [[Captain America]], she battled the Power Broker.''Captain America'' #331 Sharon later joined the [[Fantastic Four]], and alongside the Fantastic Four she battled [[Diablo (Marvel Comics)|Diablo]].''Fantastic Four'' #306-307 Shortly after joining the Fantastic Four, Sharon was mutated by cosmic rays and took on strength and appearance similar to that of Ben Grimm, a.k.a. the Thing.''Fantastic Four'' #310, Jan. 1988 Although she never officially retired her Ms. Marvel moniker, she became more popularly known as the '''She-Thing''' and it is by this name she is most known to comic book fans. She later first encountered [[Aron (comics)|Aron the Rogue Watcher]], and battled the [[She-Hulk]]. With She-Hulk, She-Thing battled [[Dragon Man]].''Fantastic Four'' #321 With the Fantastic Four and [[Frightful Four]], she was captured by Aron. They escaped and defeated their clones.''Fantastic Four'' #328-333 Sharon later battled the [[Hulk (comics)|Hulk]].''Fantastic Four'' #35 She-Thing was offered the chance to be human again by Doctor Doom while a then-powerless Ben Grimm chose to use one of Reed Richards' machines to revert to the Thing to save She-Thing.''Fantastic Four'' #350 Alongside the Fantastic Four, she battled the [[Time Variance Authority]]. She-Thing left the Fantastic Four soon after and began working for Doctor Doom. Sharon claimed to be doing this so that Doom would cure Ben as he had her.''Fantastic Four'' #352-354 She was sent by Doctor Doom to spy on the Fantastic Four, where she first met [[Alicia Masters]].''Fantastic Four'' #365-367 With [[Mister Fantastic]] and the Thing, she was captured by Aron, but rescued by the [[Molecule Man]] and Doctor Doom.''Fantastic Four'' #371-373 Alongside the Fantastic Four, she battled the [[Secret Defenders]].''Fantastic Four'' #374 Alongside the Fantastic Four, [[Lyja]], and the [[Inhumans]], she battled Doctor Doom.''Fantastic Four'' #375 When she refused to betray her friends in the Fantastic Four to Doctor Doom, Doom spitefully mutated her into a much more monstrous form.''Fantastic Four'' #378 After a bout of insanity, she briefly joined the [[Frightful Four]] and battered Sue Storm Richards to within inches of her life.''Fantastic Four Unlimited'' #5 Years later, She-Thing had a guest appearance in ''Marvel Knight''s 4, a spinoff of the main ''Fantastic Four'' book. The appearance established that she was indeed alive and well in the Marvel Universe and her attire implied she was still residing with Wingfoot. Her absence was poked fun at, as she stated that she couldn't believe anybody still had her number. Sharon Ventura was later seen again in her She-Thing form.''Fantastic Four'' #543 (March 2007) During the ''[[Secret Invasion]]'' storyline, a [[Skrull]] impersonating Sharon's "She-Thing" persona is killed by the [[Skrull Kill Krew]].''Avengers: The Initiative'' #16 The real Sharon is recovered alive from a downed Skrull ship after the final battle of the invasion.''Avengers: The Initiative'' #19 Sharon attends a support group meeting with the others who were replaced by Skrulls.''Avengers: The Initiative'' #20 Sharon has since been revealed as a prisoner in the Raft, with evidence suggesting that she is part of a plot to destabilize the Fantastic Four.''Fantastic Four Vol. 5 #9'' In the post-[[Secret Wars (2015 comic book)|Secret Wars]] Marvel Universe, Ms. Ventura has returned to her original human appearance, and has been seen wrestling in her original outfit.''Sam Wilson: Captain America #15'' ==Powers and abilities== As Ms. Marvel, Sharon had superhuman strength and endurance, thanks to augmentation of her physical attributes by Dr. Karl Malus on behalf of the Power Broker. The mutagenic effect due to exposure to cosmic radiation that turned her into the She-Thing later greatly increased her physical attributes and durability. Sharon is highly proficient in hand-to-hand combat, and skilled at various martial arts, including [[tae kwon do]] and American [[boxing]]. She is also an expert stuntwoman, scuba diver, skydiver, motorcyclist, mountain climber, skier, lion tamer, and wrestler. She attended a military academy until she was expelled. As part of Ben Grimm's Fantastic Four, she demonstrated her intelligence by solving complicated situations with her intuition and cunning.''Fantastic Four'' #324 ==In other media== ===Video games=== Sharon Ventura's Ms. Marvel appearance appears as an alternate costume for Ms. Marvel ([[Carol Danvers]]) in ''[[Marvel: Ultimate Alliance]]''.[http://vip.marvelultimatealliance.com/news.php?news_id=87 Marvel ultimatealliance] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/19700101000000/http://vip.marvelultimatealliance.com/news.php?news_id=87 |date=January 1, 1970 }} ==References== {{reflist|3}} ==External links== * [http://www.marvel.com/universe/Ms._Marvel_%28Sharon_Ventura%29 Sharon Ventura] at Marvel.com {{Fantastic Four}} {{Ms. Marvel}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ventura, Sharon}} [[Category:Characters created by Mike Carlin]] [[Category:Characters created by Ron Wilson]] [[Category:Comics characters introduced in 1985]] [[Category:Female characters in comics]] [[Category:Fictional attempted suicides]] [[Category:Fictional professional wrestlers]] [[Category:Marvel Comics characters with superhuman strength]] [[Category:Marvel Comics mutates]] [[Category:Marvel Comics superheroes]]

{{Infobox animanga character | name = Shinji Ikari | series = [[Neon Genesis Evangelion]] | image = [[File:Shinji Ikari and Asuka Langley Soryu.jpg|230px]] | caption = Shinji with [[Asuka Langley Soryu|Asuka]] directly behind | first = "[[Angel Attack]]" | creator = [[Gainax]]
[[Yoshiyuki Sadamoto]] | voiced by = '''Japanese:'''
[[Megumi Ogata]]
'''English:'''
[[Spike Spencer]] | title = Third Child
#1 | relatives = [[Gendo Ikari]] (father)
[[Yui Ikari]] (mother)
[[Rei Ayanami]] (clone of mother)
[[Misato Katsuragi]] (guardian) }} {{nihongo|'''Shinji Ikari'''|碇 シンジ|Ikari Shinji}} is a [[character (arts)|fictional character]] from the ''[[Neon Genesis Evangelion]]'' franchise created by [[Gainax]]. He is the franchise's [[poster boy]] and [[protagonist]] who is generally regarded highly by critics.{{cite web |last = Verboon | first = Nick | date =June 13, 2013 | title= 90's Flashback: Neon Genesis Evangelion |url= http://unrealitymag.com/index.php/2013/06/13/90s-flashback-neon-genesis-evangelion/ | publisher= Unreality Mag |accessdate=November 17, 2013}} Shinji is a young boy who was abandoned by his father, [[Gendo Ikari|Gendo]], who later requests him to pilot a mecha known as the [[Evangelion (mecha)#EVA Unit 01|Evangelion Unit 01]] to protect the city of Tokyo-3 from creatures known as Angels that threaten to destroy mankind. Shinji pilots Unit 01, at first rigorously and later excellently, and during his time in Tokyo-3 he is gradually freed from his [[Hedgehog's dilemma|Hedgehog's Dilemma]] as he socializes with comrades and gains friends. His talent for piloting and synchronizing Unit 01 has earned him praise from the commanding officers of NERV, an organization which Gendo leads. His toilsome duty and the cruel events of his life bring him severe stress and suffering. At some point in the series he begins to confront his inner self, forming arguments and questions about life and reality. Shinji's portrayal differs depending on the media in which he is shown such as in the official [[manga]] adaptation where he is written from the author [[Yoshiyuki Sadamoto]]'s point of view as well as other spinoff series. Shinji became highly popular, having appeared and topped in multiple popularity polls. Nick Verboon of ''Unreality Mag'' states "poster boy/protagonist Shinji is one of the most nuanced, popular, and relatable characters in anime history. ==Conception== Director [[Hideaki Anno]] described the hero, Shinji Ikari, as a boy who "shrinks from human contact", and has "convinced himself that he is a completely unnecessary person, so much so that he cannot even commit suicide." He describes Shinji and [[Misato Katsuragi]] as "extremely afraid of being hurt" and "unsuitable — lacking the positive attitude — for what people call heroes of an adventure."{{cite book | last = Sadamoto | first = Yoshiyuki | authorlink = Yoshiyuki Sadamoto | others = Essay by [[Hideaki Anno]]; translated by Mari Morimoto, English adaptation by Fred Burke | title = Neon Genesis Evangelion, Vol. 1 |date=December 1998 | origyear = July 1995 | publisher = VIZ Media LLC | location = San Francisco | isbn = 1-56931-294-X | pages = 170–171 | chapter = What were we trying to make here? }} When compared to the stereotypical hero, Shinji is characterized more by lack of energy and [[emotion]] than by heroism or bravery."This, the opening episode is constructed around all the conventions of the classic "saving the world" narrative, only to undermine them by showing IKARI [sic] Shinji, its fourteen-year-old ostensible hero, in a far from heroic light … In a more conventional anime sf narrative, Shinji would climb into the EVA with gusto and proceed to save the world. In fact he does pilot the EVA and succeeds in destroying the Angel – who turns out to be the third of seventeen – but only with the greatest reluctance and after a display of temper, fear, and vulnerability that seems less than conventionally heroic." pg 424–425 of Napier 2002 Shinji has an [[Oedipus complex]],{{cite web|url=http://x-ray001473.blog.ocn.ne.jp/iimode_do/2006/04/post_f588.html|title=エディプス・コンプレックス|date=April 23, 2003|website=X-ray001473.blog.ocn.ne.jp|quote=There was this replacement by a robot, so the original mother is the robot, but then there is a mother of the same age, Rei Ayanami, by [Shinji’s] side. [She is] also by the side of the real father. There is also another father there, Adam, who governs the overall course of events. An Oedipus Complex within these multiple structures; that’s what I wanted to do.|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110909211027/http://x-ray001473.blog.ocn.ne.jp/iimode_do/2006/04/post_f588.html|archivedate=September 9, 2011|accessdate=September 6, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.evamonkey.com/platinum-booklets/episode-commentaries-21-26.php|title=Platinum Booklets - Episode Commentaries 21-26|website=Evamonkey.com|quote=[The final] episode ends with the captions “To my father, thank you.” “To my mother, farewell.” “And to all the Children.” “Congratulations!” Eva is something of an Oedipus complex story, where a boy feels love and hatred for his father and mother, so the first two captions can be thought to means that Shinji has come to an understanding with his father and grown out of his dependence on his mother.|accessdate=September 6, 2014}} and is characterized by a [[libido]]-[[destrudo]] conflict. Shinji's relationship with his Evangelion and status as a pilot is very ambivalent; the entire series can be seen as a [[bildungsroman]] revolving around Shinji."The animation, 'Evangelion,' is a kind of bildungsroman about the soul-searching of a 14-year-old boy who has to fight mysterious enemies in a new Tokyo in the year 2015 by piloting a human-shaped robot named 'Eva.'" from Japan Economic Newswire, MAY 8, 1997, THURSDAY. "Cartoon 'Eva' captures sense of void among Japanese youth". by Yoichi Kosukegawa. TOKYO, May 8 Kyodo {{quote|"Look at Shinji. Why does he continue to fight as an Eva pilot? The story keeps changing. He said it's because everyone tells him to. Because only he can do it. Because it has to be done to save humanity. Selfless and lofty sentiments for sure, and he believed those reasons to be genuine. Wrong; he wanted his father to approve of him. To say he was a good boy. How selfish of him, really, to be a human being." --[[Megumi Hayashibara]]Quoted from "What I learned from meeting a girl who didn't know", a 1996 essay translated in Viz's English edition of ''[[Neon Genesis Evangelion, volume 3]]''}} Shinji has often been seen as a version or reflection of the creator of ''Evangelion'' and Anno has referred to the plot line as a metaphor of his life.{{cite journal |last=Wong |first=Amos |date=January 1996 |title=Interview with Hideaki Anno, director of 'Neon Genesis Evangelion' |journal=Aerial Magazine |url=http://www.aoianime.hu/evangelion/index.php?page=interanno |accessdate=May 4, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070613125248/http://www.aoianime.hu/evangelion/index.php?page=interanno|archivedate=2007-06-13 }} "Ikari" means "anchor" in Japanese. Shinji was named for [[Gainax]] co-founder [[Shinji Higuchi]]; it can be translated to "child of god."pg 121 of ''Neon Genesis Evangelion: The Unofficial Guide'', by Kazuhisa Fujie and Martin Foster, 2004, {{ISBN|0-9745961-4-0}}{{cite web | title=''Evangelion'' character names | work=Translation of essay by [[Hideaki Anno]] about character name origins; includes a link to the original essay in Japanese | url=http://www.evacommentary.org/appendix/character-names.html | accessdate=August 19, 2007 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070819093918/http://www.evacommentary.org/appendix/character-names.html | archivedate=August 19, 2007 | df= }} ''Evangelion'' character designer [[Yoshiyuki Sadamoto]] based his design of Shinji on his design of Nadia, the title character of Gainax's popular 1990-1991 TV series, ''[[Nadia: The Secret of Blue Water]]''.''[[Neon Genesis Evangelion (manga)|Neon Genesis Evangelion]]'', vol. 2, bonus materials Megumi Ogata, who voiced Shinji, found the last scene of ''End of Evangelion'' difficult to perform. Ogata regards Shinji Ikari as one of her "most memorable" roles.{{cite web|url=http://www.akadot.com/story.php?id=31 |title=Rocking the Boat |author= |date=2001-04-27 |work=interview |publisher=Digital Manga |accessdate=20 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080623173408/http://www.akadot.com/story.php?id=31 |archivedate=June 23, 2008 }} ==Appearances== ===''Neon Genesis Evangelion''=== Shinji makes his first appearance in the first episode where he is invited to Tokyo-3 by his father [[Gendo Ikari]].{{cite episode|title=Angel Attack|airdate=1995-10-04|number=1|credits=Director: Kazuya Tsurumaki, Writers:Hideaki Anno|series=Neon Genesis Evangelion|network=TV Tokyo}} Unbeknownst to Shinji however, his father told him to come so he could serve as the pilot of Evangelion Unit-01. Shinji reluctantly agrees and defeats the Angel Sachiel, initially experiencing difficulty, but brutally destroys the Angel after Unit-01 goes berserk.{{cite episode|title=The Beast|airdate=1995-10-11|number=2|credits=Director: Kazuya Tsurumaki, Writers:Hideaki Anno, Yoji Enokido|series=Neon Genesis Evangelion|network=TV Tokyo}} After the Angel attack, Shinji begins to attend school in Tokyo-3 and meets Toji Suzuhara and Kensuke Aida who would become his first true friends.{{cite episode|title=A Transfer|airdate=1995-10-18|number=3|credits=Director: Kazuya Tsurumaki, Writers:Hideaki Anno, Akio Satsukawa|series=Neon Genesis Evangelion|network=TV Tokyo}} When the Angel Ramiel appears and attempts to destroy Nerv headquarters, Shinji and fellow pilot [[Rei Ayanami]] work together to destroy the Angel.{{cite episode|title=Rei II|airdate=1995-11-08|number=6|credits=Director: Hiroyuki Ishido, Writers:Hideaki Anno, Akio Satsukawa|series=Neon Genesis Evangelion|network=TV Tokyo}} When a nuclear-powered machine intended to fight the Angels runs amok, he and his guardian Misato successfully stop it. Shinji later meets [[Asuka Langley Soryu]], an eva-pilot from Germany, and the two successfully defeat Gaghiel.{{cite episode|title=Asuka Strikes!|airdate=1995-11-01|number=8|credits=Director: Kazuya Tsurumaki, Writers:Hideaki Anno, Yoki Enokido|series=Neon Genesis Evangelion|network=TV Tokyo}} Shinji, Rei and Asuka assault the explosive angel Sahaquiel, risking their lives to the extreme in order to do so. They defeat the Angel thanks mostly to Shinji's efforts. Shinji later gains supreme synchronization skill, causing Shinji to realize that he was born to pilot the Eva, and he receives praise from the commanding officers of NERV. Shinji, Rei and Asuka are later sent to fight the dark Angel Leliel, whose reverse AT field sucks Shinji into a parallel universe. Shinji confronts the Angel, during which he also confronts his inner self, forming arguments and philosophies. He is brutally freed from the powerful Angel through the intervention of his mother Yui, whose soul is within the Eva, which epically, gruesomely splits the Angel's massive body into two. After Shinji is forced to fight the Bardiel-controlled Eva-03 while Toji is trapped within,{{cite episode|title=Ambivalence|airdate=1996-01-31|number=18|credits=Director: Tensai Okamura, Writers:Hideaki Anno, Shinji Higuchi|series=Neon Genesis Evangelion|network=TV Tokyo}} Shinji decides to quit Nerv. Zeruel soon appears and decapitates the other Evangelion units.{{cite episode|title=Introjection|airdate=1996-02-07|number=19|credits=Director: Masayuki, Writers:Hideaki Anno, Akio Satsukawa|series=Neon Genesis Evangelion|network=TV Tokyo}} Shinji realizes that only he can defeat it, and returns to NERV. Midway during the battle, however, Unit-01's power supply runs out, eventually causing Shinji to attain a 400% sync ratio with the unit, allowing him to continue his assault and frees the Evangelion in the process. As a result, he is trapped within its core for a month before being released.{{cite episode|title=Weaving a Story 2: Oral Stage|airdate=1996-02-14|number=20|credits=Director: Masahiko Ohtsuka, Writers:Hideaki Anno|series=Neon Genesis Evangelion|network=TV Tokyo}} After Rei sacrifices herself to save Shinji and then is subsequently revived through one of her clones while Asuka becomes comatose,{{cite episode|title=Rei III|airdate=1996-03-06|number=23|credits=Director: Shoichi Masuo, Writers:Hideaki Anno, Hiroshi Yamaguchi|series=Neon Genesis Evangelion|network=TV Tokyo}} Shinji begins to suffer with depression. He meets [[Kaworu Nagisa]] and the two become friends. However, it is later revealed that Kaworu is in fact the final Angel and Shinji is forced to kill him,{{cite episode|title=The Beginning and the End, or 'Knockin' on Heaven's Door|airdate=1996-03-13|number=24|credits=Director: Shoichi Masuo, Writers:Hideaki Anno, Akio Satsukawa|series=Neon Genesis Evangelion|network=TV Tokyo}} giving Shinji extreme mental trauma. ===''The End of Evangelion''=== ''[[The End of Evangelion]]'' continues Shinji's story, portraying his downward spiral into depression and eventual loss of the will to live. He is in this state for the majority of the film, remaining catatonic while all the NERV officers, including Misato, are killed. Shinji then decides to pilot the Eva to save those who are still alive, but a bakelite release ordered by Misato accidentally blocks the entrance of Unit-01. When Shinji learns of Asuka's defeat, the Evangelion moves on its own to let Shinji become the transcendent, powerful hero once again. Shinji's Ego cause the Eva's AT field to manifest in the form of gigantic, dreadful, divine wings. Despite this, after witnessing the mangled, mutilated corpse of Unit-02 being carried by the Mass Production Evas, Shinji's trauma becomes even worse as the Human Instrumentality Project begins. Shinji's intense emotion summons the Lance of Longinus stuck on the Moon all the way down to Earth. Shinji's Ego continues to resist Lilith-Rei and SEELE's assaults on his soul; but when Lilith-Rei takes the form of Kaworu Nagisa, Shinji's Ego weakens, as Yui's soul from inside the Eva tells Shinji that Rei is "all of Shinji's hopes and dreams". Lilith-Rei and SEELE ultimately defeat Shinji's Ego. The fusion of the Lance of Longinus with the Eva recreates a Tree of Life. Shinji and the Eva, now possessing both the Fruit of Wisdom and the Fruit of Life, become "God". Shinji, now one with all other humans, converses with them, particularly Rei and Kaworu. It is revealed that Shinji and Eva's absorption of a Fruit of Life and a Fruit of Wisdom meant that Eva, and the pilot inside, will continue to exist forever, "even after the Sun, the Moon, and the planets are gone". He eventually converses with Yui, whom he wonders what will do, until he finally decides that he wants to live and returns to Earth. Asuka appears next to him and Shinji attempts to strangle her for an un-clarified reason, but stops himself and breaks down after Asuka regains consciousness and caresses his face. ===''Rebuild of Evangelion''=== In ''[[Rebuild of Evangelion]]'' Shinji returns as the central protagonist in ''[[Evangelion: 1.0 You Are (Not) Alone]]'', where he is shown to be more outspoken than his TV counterpart. In this film, Shinji's role is very much the same as that of the anime series. He is assigned to be the pilot of Unit-01 and works alongside Rei to defeat the Angel Ramiel.{{cite video | people = [[Hideaki Anno]], [[Kazuya Tsurumaki]], Masayuki (directors) | title = [[Evangelion: 1.0 You Are (Not) Alone]] | medium = [[Film]] | publisher = [[Studio Khara]] |date = 2007}} In ''[[Evangelion: 2.0 You Can (Not) Advance]]'', Shinji continues his duties as pilot of Unit-01, albeit reluctantly. After the battle with Bardiel, wherein his father forced him to critically injure Asuka, Shinji retires from his duties and leaves NERV. When Zeruel consumes Rei, Shinji returns and defeats the Angel by seemingly fusing with the Evangelion. In ''[[Evangelion: 3.0 You Can (Not) Redo]]'', set fifteen years later, Shinji is awakened to a changed world caused by the Third Impact which he started. Everyone treats Shinji poorly, except Kaworu. A clone of Rei now pilots Mark 09, aka The Vessel of Adams. After Shinji realizes that he did not save Rei, he and Kaworu pilot Eva-13, one of the Four Adams and the most powerful known Evangelion which the two operate. They attempt to erase Third Impact by using the spears of Longinus and Cassius allegedly lodged in Lilith, but instead start Fourth impact after Shinji pulls the two spears of Longinus out from Lilith, ignoring Kaworu and Asuka's warning. Eva-13 then eats the Twelfth Angel and ascends to divinity. However, Kaworu sacrifices himself to stop the Fourth Impact, leaving Shinji losing his will to live.{{cite video | people = [[Hideaki Anno]], [[Kazuya Tsurumaki]], Masayuki (directors) | title = [[Evangelion: 2.0 You Can (Not) Advance]] | medium = [[Film]] | publisher = [[Studio Khara]] |date = 2009}} The fourth film is yet to be released. ===In other media=== {{refimprove section|date=April 2009}} Shinji appears in most manga adaptations of ''Neon Genesis Evangelion'', including [[Yoshiyuki Sadamoto]]'s [[Neon Genesis Evangelion (manga)|manga adaptation]]. The manga generally follows the plot of the anime with occasional alterations in events. In this manga, Shinji's role is very similar to his anime counterpart, although changes in characterization are apparent. This is due to the fact the manga is written from Sadamoto's point of view involving Shinji. Sadamoto was inspired to write the manga after learning of Shinji's role in the first episode of the television series. Shinji is also a primary protagonist in ''[[Neon Genesis Evangelion: Shinji Ikari Raising Project|the Shinji Ikari Raising Project]]'' and ''[[Neon Genesis Evangelion: Campus Apocalypse]]'' where he is portrayed in a different light than his anime counterpart. Shinji, alongside other ''Evangelion'' characters, makes frequent appearances in video games, such as ''[[Neon Genesis Evangelion (video game)|Neon Genesis Evangelion]]'' for the [[Nintendo 64]]. Shinji is also a playable character in the popular cross-over video game franchise [[Super Robot Wars]] where he and other ''Evangelion'' characters work with characters from various other [[mecha]] series. ==Reception== Shinji has received critical acclaim as a character. Shinji ranked 25th on [[IGN]]'s first top 25 anime characters list. Editor Chris Mackenzie commented that the IGN staff loved him "not for what he is, but for what he could be".{{cite web |title=Top 25 Anime Characters of All Time |url=http://movies.ign.com/articles/103/1036651p1.html |publisher=[[IGN]] |accessdate=2009-10-22 |date=2009-10-20}} In 2014, IGN ranked him as the greatest anime character of all time, observing that he is a "genuine work of art", saying that heroes "are often who we want to be", and noting he was different from it: "he was perhaps the most emotionally true-to-life character in anime history."{{cite web | url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/02/04/top-25-greatest-anime-characters?page=5 | title=Top 25 Greatest Anime Characters | author=Isler, Ramsey | date=February 4, 2014 | publisher=IGN | accessdate=March 13, 2014}} In a ''[[Newtype]]'' poll from March 2010, Shinji was voted as the most popular male character from the 1990s.{{cite journal |journal=[[Newtype]], Issue 4|date=March 2010|publisher=[[Kadokawa Shoten]]|title=NT Research}} The 19th and the 20th ''[[Animage]]'' Grand Prix ranked him the best male character of the year.{{cite web|url=http://animage.jp/old/gp/gp_1997.html|script-title=ja:第19回アニメグランプリ 1997年6月号|language=Japanese|publisher=[[Animage]]|accessdate=April 11, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5vS3xHqrF?url=http://animage.jp/old/gp/gp_1997.html|archivedate=January 3, 2011|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://animage.jp/old/gp/gp_1998.html|script-title=ja:第20回アニメグランプリ 1998年6月号|language=Japanese|publisher=[[Animage]]|accessdate=April 11, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5vS3xHqrM?url=http://animage.jp/old/gp/gp_1998.html|archivedate=January 3, 2011|df=}} Pete Harcoff, a reviewer for Anime Critic, gave a positive review of ''Neon Genesis Evangelion'' yet maintained a negative view of Shinji's character, stating that Shinji was ineffective and disappointing to watch.{{cite web|url=http://www.animecritic.com/evangelion/anr-evangelion.html|title=Neon Genesis Evangelion|author=Pete Harcoff|date=May 26, 2003|work=|publisher=|accessdate=29 June 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131004215400/http://www.animecritic.com/evangelion/anr-evangelion.html|archivedate=4 October 2013|df=}} Shinji's role in the Rebuild of Evangelion films got a better response as he was noted to be friendlier with other characters in contrast to his role in the TV series.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/review/evangelion/1.0.1-you-are-not-alone/dub-version|title=Evangelion: 1.0.1 You Are [Not] Alone (dub version)|date=July 9, 2009|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|author=Santos, Carlo|accessdate=December 2, 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/review/evangelion/2.0-you-can-not-advance|title=Evangelion: 2.0 You Can [Not] Advance|date=November 24, 2009|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|author=Sevakis, Justin|accessdate=December 2, 2009}} Theron Martin from [[Anime News Network]] listed the scene from ''[[Evangelion: 2.22 You Can (Not) Advance]]'' in which Shinji saves Rei as the "Best Scene" in the site's feature "The Best (and Most Notable) of 2011." Martin praised Shinji's determination in such scene as "this is the first time in the entire franchise that he whole-heartedly goes after something because he ''wants'' it, rather than because he's expected to or has no choice."{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/feature/2012-01-05|title=Anime in America: The Best (and Most Notable) of 2011|date=January 5, 2012|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|author=Theron, Martin|accessdate=November 26, 2012}} [[Spike Spencer]], Shinji's English voice actor, has received praise for his role, particularly for his performance in ''The End of Evangelion''. Mike Crandol of [[Anime News Network]] praised the subtle nuances that Spencer brought to the role, as he felt that Spencer had improved over his previous performances where he tended to parody Shinji's inner turmoil.{{cite web |url= http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/review/end-of-evangelion-dvd|title= Neon Genesis Evangelion: End of Evangelion |author= Mike Crandol |date= September 24, 2002|work= |publisher= |accessdate=29 June 2011}} Pete Harcoff, while critical of Shinji's character, also complimented Spencer, stating that he delivered a solid performance as Shinji.{{cite web|url=http://www.animecritic.com/evangelion/anr-endofevangelion.html|title=End of Evangelion|author=Pete Harcoff|date=June 6, 2003|work=|publisher=|accessdate=29 June 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928080610/http://www.animecritic.com/evangelion/anr-endofevangelion.html|archivedate=28 September 2011|df=}} Nick Verboon of ''Unreality Mag'' states "poster boy/protagonist Shinji is one of the most nuanced, popular, and relatable characters in anime history. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Refbegin}} * {{cite journal |last=Napier |first=Susan J. |authorlink=Susan J. Napier |date=November 2002 |title=When the Machines Stop: Fantasy, Reality, and Terminal Identity in ''Neon Genesis Evangelion'' and ''Serial Experiments Lain'' |journal=Science Fiction Studies |volume=29 |issue=88 |pages=418–435 |url= http://www.depauw.edu/sfs/abstracts/a88.htm#Napier|accessdate=2007-05-04}} {{Refend}} {{Neon Genesis Evangelion}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ikari, Shinji}} [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 1994]] [[Category:Fictional characters with neurological or psychological disorders]] [[Category:Fictional cellists]] [[Category:Fictional child soldiers]] [[Category:Fictional Japanese people]] [[Category:Fictional Japanese people in anime and manga]] [[Category:Fictional mass murderers]] [[Category:Fictional private military members]] [[Category:Male characters in anime and manga]] [[Category:Neon Genesis Evangelion characters]] [[Category:Science fiction film characters]] [[Category:Teenage characters in television]] [[Category:Teenage characters in anime and manga]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=January 2017}} [[File:Suriya at Inam screening.jpg|thumb|alt=Suriya in a dark, long-sleeved shirt posing for the camera|[[Suriya]] at the premiere of ''[[Ceylon (film)|Ceylon]]'' in 2014]] [[Suriya]] is an Indian actor and producer who works primarily in [[Tamil language]] films. He made a commercially successful cinematic debut in [[Vasanth]]'s ''[[Nerrukku Ner]]'' (1997).{{cite web | url=http://www.rediff.com/movies/slide-show/slide-show-1-looking-at-suriyas-landmark-films/20111020.htm | title=Looking at Suriya's landmark films | publisher=[[Rediff.com]] | date=20 October 2011 | accessdate=15 January 2017 | last=Srinivasan | first=Pavithra | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170115114925/http://www.rediff.com/movies/slide-show/slide-show-1-looking-at-suriyas-landmark-films/20111020.htm | archivedate=15 January 2017}}{{cite web |url=http://specials.rediff.com/movies/2008/nov/11sli1.htm |title=The best of Surya |publisher=Rediff.com |last=Srinivasan |first=Pavithra |date=11 November 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170116144226/http://specials.rediff.com/movies/2008/nov/11sli1.htm |archivedate=16 January 2017 |accessdate=13 January 2017}} This was followed by roles in a series of critical and commercial failures, including ''[[Kaadhale Nimmadhi]]'' (1998), ''[[Sandhippoma]]'' (1998) and ''[[Periyanna]]'' (1999).{{cite news | url=http://www.thehindu.com/2000/06/09/stories/09090224.htm | title=Each step is a measured one | work=[[The Hindu]] | date=9 June 2000 | accessdate=16 January 2017 | last=Rangarajan | first=Malathi | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170116123648/http://www.thehindu.com/2000/06/09/stories/09090224.htm | archivedate=16 January 2017}} Suriya collaborated with Vasanth again in ''[[Poovellam Kettuppar]]'' (1999), his first film with future wife [[Jyothika]].{{cite news | authorlink1=Sudhish Kamath | url=http://www.thehindu.com/2001/07/11/stories/0411401v.htm | title=Talk of the Town | work=The Hindu | date=11 July 2001 | accessdate=16 January 2017 | first1=Sudhish | last1=Kamath | last2=Shankar | first2=T.S. | last3=Radhakrishnan | first3=R.K. | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170116123338/http://www.thehindu.com/2001/07/11/stories/0411401v.htm | archivedate=16 January 2017}} In 2001, Suriya starred in [[Bala (director)|Bala]]'s ''[[Nandha]]'' as an ex-convict trying to find his place in society.{{cite web | url=http://www.outlookindia.com/magazine/story/singam-on-song/286838 | title=Singam On Song | work=[[Outlook (magazine)|Outlook]] | date=22 July 2013 | accessdate=17 January 2017 | last=Ramachandran | first=Naman | authorlink=Naman Ramachandran | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170117161035/http://www.outlookindia.com/magazine/story/singam-on-song/286838 | archivedate=17 January 2017}} The film was critically acclaimed and became a turning point in his career.{{cite news | url=http://www.thehindu.com/thehindu/mp/2002/07/24/stories/2002072400140200.htm | title=A chip off the old block | work=The Hindu | date=24 July 2002 | accessdate=17 January 2017 | last=Pillai | first=Sreedhar | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170117083719/http://www.thehindu.com/thehindu/mp/2002/07/24/stories/2002072400140200.htm | archivedate=17 January 2017}}{{cite web | url=http://www.news18.com/news/movies/happy-birthday-suriya-5-performances-that-make-him-the-singam-of-tamil-cinema-1024604.html | title=Happy Birthday Suriya: 5 performances that make him the 'Singam' of Tamil cinema | publisher=[[CNN-News18]] | date=23 July 2015 | accessdate=17 January 2017 | last=Rajpal | first=Roktim | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170117083853/http://www.news18.com/news/movies/18-years-of-suriya-how-a-garment-factory-worker-turned-into-the-most-bankable-tamil-star-1079969.html | archivedate=17 January 2017}} His roles as a police officer in [[Gautham Menon]]'s 2003 [[action film]] ''[[Kaakha Kaakha]]'' and a [[Confidence trick|con man]] in Bala's drama, ''[[Pithamagan]]'' (2003), established him as one of Tamil cinema's leading actors.{{cite news | url=http://www.thehindu.com/thehindu/mp/2003/12/29/stories/2003122900170100.htm | title=Reel of fortune | work=The Hindu | date=29 December 2003 | accessdate=17 January 2017 | last=Pillai | first=Sreedhar | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170117085958/http://www.thehindu.com/thehindu/mp/2003/12/29/stories/2003122900170100.htm | archivedate=17 January 2017}} Suriya's performances in both films were praised, winning him a [[Filmfare Award for Best Actor – Tamil|Best Actor]] nomination for the former and the [[Filmfare Award for Best Supporting Actor – Tamil|Best Supporting Actor]] for ''Pithamagan'' at the [[51st Filmfare Awards South]].{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/hindi/bollywood/news/51st-Annual-Manikchand-Filmfare-Award-winners/articleshow/718496.cms |title=51st Annual Manikchand Filmfare Award winners |work=[[The Times of India]] |date=4 June 2004 |accessdate=28 March 2016 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20150126140422/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/hindi/bollywood/news/51st-Annual-Manikchand-Filmfare-Award-winners/articleshow/718496.cms |archivedate=26 January 2015 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The following year, he played [[dual role]]s—a hunchback and a college student—in ''[[Perazhagan]]''. Suriya's performance was again praised, and he received his first [[52nd Filmfare Awards South|Filmfare Best Actor award]].{{cite news | url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/mumbai/entertainment/twice-as-nice/article8488429.ece | title=Twice as nice | work=The Hindu | date=18 April 2016 | accessdate=17 January 2017 | last=Surendran | first=Anusha | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170305081344/http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/mumbai/entertainment/twice-as-nice/article8488429.ece | archivedate=5 March 2017}} He was also acclaimed for his performance as a student leader in [[Mani Ratnam]]'s ''[[Aaytha Ezhuthu]]'' (2004). In 2005, Suriya starred in three films: ''[[Maayavi]]'', ''[[Ghajini (2005 film)|Ghajini]]'' and ''[[Aaru (film)|Aaru]]''. His performance in ''Ghajini'' as a businessman with [[anterograde amnesia]] was widely praised.{{cite news | url=http://www.thehindu.com/thehindu/fr/2005/12/30/stories/2005123001140100.htm | title=Tamil cinema's new high | work=The Hindu | date=30 December 2005 | accessdate=19 January 2017 | last=Pillai | first=Sreedhar | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141004052839/http://www.thehindu.com/thehindu/fr/2005/12/30/stories/2005123001140100.htm | archivedate=4 October 2014}} ''Maayavi'' and ''Aaru'' were moderately successful.{{cite web | url=http://www.sify.com/movies/boxoffice.php?id=plupk4hgbcbec | title=Chennai box-office (Mar 25{{ndash}}27) | publisher=[[Sify]] | date=30 March 2005 | accessdate=19 January 2017 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170119103452/http://www.sify.com/movies/boxoffice.php?id=plupk4hgbcbec | archivedate=19 January 2017}}{{cite web | url=http://www.sify.com/movies/boxoffice.php?id=plupluegfdhgb | title=Chennai box-office (Jan 06{{ndash}}08) | publisher=Sify | date=10 January 2006 | accessdate=19 January 2017 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170119104939/http://www.sify.com/movies/boxoffice.php?id=plupluegfdhgb | archivedate=19 January 2017}} Over the next two years, Suriya starred in ''[[Sillunu Oru Kaadhal]]'' (2006) and ''[[Vel (film)|Vel]]'' (2007). Although the former was a [[box office bomb]],{{cite web | url=http://www.sify.com/movies/boxoffice.php?id=plupmnajhhhhf | title=Chennai box-office(Oct 06{{ndash}}08) | publisher=Sify | date=10 October 2006 | accessdate=19 January 2017 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170119103457/http://www.sify.com/movies/boxoffice.php?id=plupmnajhhhhf | archivedate=19 January 2017}} ''Vel'', where he played twins, was commercially successful.{{cite web|url=http://www.sify.com/movies/vel-review-tamil-pclwzbfegcihb.html |title=Vel |publisher=Sify |date=9 November 2007 |accessdate=15 January 2017 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170115133448/http://www.sify.com/movies/vel-review-tamil-pclwzbfegcihb.html |archivedate=15 January 2017 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{cite news|url=http://epaper.timesofindia.com/Default/Scripting/ArticleWin.asp?From=Archive&Source=Page&Skin=TOI&BaseHref=TOICH/2008/10/24&PageLabel=25&EntityId=Ar02500&ViewMode=HTML&GZ=T |title=Diwali dampeners |work=The Times of India |date=24 October 2008 |accessdate=19 January 2017 |last=Pillai |first=Sreedhar |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170119104447/http://epaper.timesofindia.com/Default/Scripting/ArticleWin.asp?From=Archive&Source=Page&Skin=TOI&BaseHref=TOICH%2F2008%2F10%2F24&PageLabel=25&EntityId=Ar02500&ViewMode=HTML&GZ=T |archivedate=19 January 2017 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Suriya's next appearance was in the [[Romance film|romantic drama]], ''[[Vaaranam Aayiram]]'' (2008).{{cite news | url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-features/tp-fridayreview/An-ode-to-dad-dearest-Vaaranam-Aayiram/article15400806.ece | title=An ode to dad dearest — Vaaranam Aayiram | work=The Hindu | date=21 November 2008 | accessdate=15 January 2017 | last=Rangarajan | first=Malathi | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170115134248/http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-features/tp-fridayreview/An-ode-to-dad-dearest-Vaaranam-Aayiram/article15400806.ece | archivedate=15 January 2017}} His dual role as father and son earned him another Filmfare Best Actor award.{{cite web | url=http://www.sify.com/movies/56th-filmfare-awards-2008-given-away-news-tamil-kkfrEufbgecsi.html | title=56th Filmfare Awards 2008 given away | publisher=Sify | date=3 August 2009 | accessdate=19 January 2017 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170119121245/http://www.sify.com/movies/56th-filmfare-awards-2008-given-away-news-tamil-kkfrEufbgecsi.html | archivedate=19 January 2017}} Suriya's next three films were ''[[Ayan (film)|Ayan]]'' (2009), ''[[Aadhavan]]'' (2009) and ''[[Singam]]'' (2010). The latter, in which he starred with [[Anushka Shetty]], was his most commercially successful film to date and spawned two sequels: ''[[Singam II]]'' (2013) and ''[[Si3 (film)|Si3]]'' (2017).{{cite web | url=http://www.rediff.com/movies/slide-show/slide-show-1-birthday-special-10-best-films-of-suriya-south/20140723.htm | title=Birthday Special: 10 Best Films of Suriya | publisher=Rediff.com | date=23 July 2014 | accessdate=19 January 2017 | last=Saraswathi | first=S | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170119124913/http://www.rediff.com/movies/slide-show/slide-show-1-birthday-special-10-best-films-of-suriya-south/20140723.htm | archivedate=19 January 2017}}{{cite web | url=http://www.sify.com/movies/s3-now-becomes-c3-for-tax-exemption-news-tamil-rbrjIWhfheief.html | title=S3 now becomes C3 for tax-exemption! | publisher=Sify | date=17 January 2017 | accessdate=18 January 2017 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170118154617/http://www.sify.com/movies/s3-now-becomes-c3-for-tax-exemption-news-tamil-rbrjIWhfheief.html | archivedate=18 January 2017}}{{efn|''Singam'' was Suriya's 25th film.}} The actor made his [[Hindi]] and [[Telugu cinema]] debuts in [[Ram Gopal Varma]]'s two-part [[Mob film|gangster drama]] ''[[Rakta Charitra]]'' (2010).{{cite news | url=http://www.mid-day.com/articles/birthday-special-vivek-oberois-5-memorable-performances/16506199 | title=Birthday special: Vivek Oberoi's 5 memorable performances | work=[[Mid Day]] | date=3 September 2015 | accessdate=16 January 2017 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170116100205/http://www.mid-day.com/articles/birthday-special-vivek-oberois-5-memorable-performances/16506199 | archivedate=16 January 2017}} Suriya then played the [[Bhikkhu|Buddhist monk]] and creator of [[Shaolin Kung Fu]], [[Bodhidharma]], and his fictional descendant Aravind, in ''[[7aum Arivu]]'' (2011).{{cite web | url=http://www.rediff.com/movies/report/review-seven-am-arivu/20111026.htm | title=Review: 7am Arivu is worth a watch | publisher=Rediff.com | date=26 October 2011 | accessdate=15 January 2017 | last=Srinivasan | first=Pavithra | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170115162548/http://www.rediff.com/movies/report/review-seven-am-arivu/20111026.htm | archivedate=15 January 2017}}{{cite news | url=http://www.thehindu.com/features/metroplus/education-will-give-flight-to-girls-anandmurti-gurumaa/article8249133.ece | title='Education will give flight to girls': Anandmurti Gurumaa | work=The Hindu | date=17 February 2016 | accessdate=19 January 2017 | last=Parsai | first=Gargi | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170119130850/http://www.thehindu.com/features/metroplus/education-will-give-flight-to-girls-anandmurti-gurumaa/article8249133.ece | archivedate=19 January 2017}} His only 2012 release was ''[[Maattrraan]]'', in which he played [[conjoined twins]].{{cite web | url=http://www.rediff.com/movies/report/south-review-maattraan-is-not-up-to-the-mark/20121012.htm | title=Review: Maattrraan is not up to the mark | publisher=Rediff.com | date=12 October 2012 | accessdate=15 January 2017 | last=Srinivasan | first=Pavithra | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170115161957/http://www.rediff.com/movies/report/south-review-maattraan-is-not-up-to-the-mark/20121012.htm | archivedate=15 January 2017}} In 2015, Suriya released ''[[36 Vayadhinile]]'', the first film from his [[2D Entertainment]] production company.{{cite news | url=http://www.thehindu.com/features/cinema/gnanavel-raja-speaks-on-suriyas-24/article8551774.ece | title="Suriya has Rs.50 crore market potential in Andhra, Telangana" | work=The Hindu | date=3 May 2016 | accessdate=19 January 2017 | last=Menon | first=Vishal | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170119131016/http://www.thehindu.com/features/cinema/gnanavel-raja-speaks-on-suriyas-24/article8551774.ece | archivedate=19 January 2017}} He played three roles for the first time in [[Vikram Kumar]]'s [[science fiction film]], ''[[24 (2016 film)|24]]'' (2016).{{cite web | url=http://www.sify.com/movies/five-reasons-why-you-should-watch-24-news-tamil-qffjX7idahecg.html | title=Five reasons why you should watch 24 | publisher=Sify | date=5 May 2016 | accessdate=19 January 2017 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170119132201/http://www.sify.com/movies/five-reasons-why-you-should-watch-24-news-tamil-qffjX7idahecg.html | archivedate=19 January 2017}} It became one of the year's highest-grossing Tamil films and his performances earned him a [[Filmfare Critics Award for Best Actor – South|Critics Award for Best Actor]] at Filmfare.{{cite news | url=http://www.thehindu.com/entertainment/movies/Kollywood%E2%80%99s-2016-report-card/article16937524.ece | title=Kollywood’s 2016 report card | work=The Hindu | date=24 December 2016 | accessdate=19 January 2017 | last=Pillai | first=Sreedhar | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170119131702/http://www.thehindu.com/entertainment/movies/Kollywood%E2%80%99s-2016-report-card/article16937524.ece | archivedate=19 January 2017}}{{cite news | url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/tamil/movies/news/winners-64th-jio-filmfare-awards-south/articleshow/59192157.cms | title=Winners: 64th Jio Filmfare Awards (South) | work=The Times of India | date=18 June 2017 | accessdate=18 June 2017 | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6rJ496Tl8?url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/tamil/movies/news/winners-64th-jio-filmfare-awards-south/articleshow/59192157.cms | archivedate=18 June 2017 | deadurl=yes | df=dmy-all }} == Films == {| class="wikitable" |+Key | style="background:#FFFFCC;"| {{dagger|alt=Films that have not yet been released}} | Denotes films that have not yet been released |} *''All films are in Tamil, unless otherwise noted.'' === As an actor === {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders sortable" style="margin-right: 0;" |- ! scope="col"|Film !
